div.p: SPEED THE PLOUGH: A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
By THOMAS MORTON, Eſq. AUTHOR OF "A CURE FOR THE HEART ACHE," "WAY TO GET MARRIED," &c. &c.
THE SECOND EDITION.
LONDON; PRINTED BY A. STRAHAN, PRINTERS-STREET; FOR T. N. LONGMAN AND O. REES, PATERNOSTER-ROW.
[Price Two Shillings.]

div.head: PROLOGUE,
div.byline: Written by W. T. FITZGERALD, Eſq SPOKEN BY MR. BETTERTON.

lg.l: IN ev'ry age, the trump of deathleſs fame
Proclaims the warrior's and the poet's name;
Painting and ſculpture all the pow'rs combine,
And laurels deck the bard's and hero's ſhrine.
No further can the parallel extend,
The poet's honours on ſucceſs depend;
While Fortune's frown can ne'er moleſt the brave,
Nor blaſt the laurel ſpringing from his grave.
An equal wreath impartial Fame ſupplies,
To him who conquers, and to him who dies;
For Britiſh valor was diſplayed, not more
On Nile's proud flood, than Helder's barren ſhore!
The chance of war the braveſt may control,
But leaves untouch'd the courage of the ſoul;
And England gives her heroes, ever dear!
The ſhout of triumph, or the ſtarting tear.
Not ſo the Bard—with him ſucceſs is all!
When Fortune frowns, his air-built caſtles fall:
But if ſhe ſmiles, he ſails with proſperous breeze,
Like the ſmall Nautilus o'er Summer ſeas;
Whoſe little oars on ocean's boſom ſweep,
Fearleſs of all the monſters of the deep.
Oft at this Bar, our Author has been tried,
Where Engliſh Judges take the pris'ner's ſide!
Guilty of faults no doubt he will appear,
But human errors find acquittal here—
Where e'en the friendleſs always meet ſupport,
From honeſt Juries, and an upright Court.
Critics, who rule o'er politics and plays,
If you are adverſe, vain the poet's lays!
"You, who with equal hands the balance hold,
"Whoſe juſt deciſion ne'er was bought or ſold,
"But who to ev'ry candidate diſpenſe
"His lot of humour, and his ſhare of ſenſe,"
Protect our Author on the coming day,
And though you damn the Prologue—ſpare the Play:
To your decree each Dramatiſt muſt bow,
Give but your aid, and that will "Speed the Plough!"

div.p: The lines marked with inverted commas were omitted.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
SPEED THE PLOUGH.
ACT I.
SCENE I.—In the fore-ground a Farm Houſe— A view of a Caſtle at a diſtance.
div.stage: Farmer ASHFIELD diſcovered with his jug and pipe.
Enter Dame ASHFIELD in a riding dreſs, and a baſket under her arm.

sp.speaker: ASHFIELD.
sp.p: WELL, Dame, welcome whoam. What news does thee bring vrom market?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: What news, huſband? What I always told you; that Farmer Grundy's wheat brought five ſhillings a quarter more than ours did.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: All the better vor he.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ah! the ſun ſeems to ſhine on purpoſe for him.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Come, come, Miſſus, as thee has not the grace to thank God for proſperous times, dan't thee grumble when they be unkindly a bit.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And I aſſure you Dame Grundy's butter was quite the crack of the market.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Be quiet, woolye? aleways ding, dinging Dame Grundy into my ears—what will Mrs. Grundy zay? What will Mrs. Grundy think?— Casn't thee be quiet, let ur alone, and behave thyzel pratty?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Certainly I can—I'll tell thee, Tummas, what ſhe ſaid at church laſt Sunday.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Canſt thee tell what parſon zaid? Noa— Then I'll tell thee—A' zaid that envy were as foul a weed as grows, and cankers all wholeſome plants that be near it—that's what a'zaid.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And do you think I envy Mrs. Grundy indeed?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What dant thee letten her aloane then—I do verily think when thee goeſt to t'other world, the vurſt queſtion thee't ax 'il be, if Mrs. Grundy's there—Zoa be quiet, and behave pratty, do'ye— Has thee brought whoam the Saliſbury news?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: No, Tummas; but I have brought a rare wadget of news with me. Firſt and foremoſt I ſaw ſuch a mort of coaches, ſervants, and waggons, all belonging to Sir Abel Handy, and all coming to the Caſtle—and a handſome young man, dreſſed all in lace, pull'd off his hat to me, and ſaid— Mrs. Aſhfield, do me the honour of preſenting that letter to your huſband.—So, there he ſtood without his hat—Oh, Tummas, had you ſeen how Mrs. Grundy looked!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dom Mrs. Grundy—be quiet, and let I read, woolye? (reads) "My dear Farmer" (taking off his hat), Thankye, Zur—zame to you we all my heart and ſoul—" My dear Farmer"—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Farmer—Why, you are blind, Tummas; it is—" My dear Father"—'Tis from our own dear Suſan.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Odds! dickens and daizeys! zoo it be, zure enow!—"My dear Feyther, you will be ſurprized"—Zoo I be, he, he! What pretty writing, beant it? all as ſtrait as thof it were ploughed— Surpriſed to hear that in a few hours I ſhall embrace you—Nelly, who formerly was our ſervant, has fortunately married Sir Abel Handy Bart.—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Handy Bart—Pugh! Bart. ſtands for Baronight, mun.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Likely, likely—Drabbit it, only to think of the zwaps and changes of this world!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Our Nelly married to a great Baronet! I wonder, Tummas, what Mrs. Grundy will ſay?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Now, woolye be quiet, and let I read— And ſhe has propoſed bringing me to ſee you; an offer, I hope, as acceptable to my dear feyther—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: "And mother"—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Bleſs her, how prettily ſhe do write feyther, dant ſhe?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And mother.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, but feyther firſt, though— As acceptable to my dear feyther and mother, as to their affectionate daughter—Suſan Aſhfield— Now beant that a pratty letter?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And, Tummas, is not ſhe a pretty girl?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees; and as good as ſhe be pratty— Drabbit it, I do feel zoo happy, and zoo warm,— for all the world like the zun in harveſt.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Oh, Tummas, I ſhall be ſo pleaſed to ſee her, I ſhan't know whether I ſtand on my head or my heels.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Stand on thy head! vor ſheame o'thyzel— behave pratty, do.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Nay, I meant no harm—Eh, here comes friend Evergreen the gardner, from the Caſtle. Bleſs me, what a hurry the old man is in.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Good day, honeſt Thomas.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Zame to you, meaſter Evergreen.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Have you heard the news?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Anything about Mrs. Grundy?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dame, be quiet, woolye now?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: No, no—The news is, that my maſter, Sir Philip Blandford, after having been abroad for twenty years, returns this day to the Caſtle; and that the reaſon of his coming, is to marry his only daughter to the ſon of Sir Abel Handy, I think they call him.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: As ſure as twopence, that is Nelly's huſband.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Indeed!—Well, Sir Abel and his ſon will be here immediately; and, Farmer, you muſt attend them.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Likely, likely.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: And, miſtreſs, come and lend us a hand at the Caſtle, will you?—Ah, twenty long years ſince I have ſeen Sir Philip—Poor Gentleman! bad, bad health—worn almoſt to the grave, I am told.—What a lad do I remember him—till that dreadful— (checking himſelf.) But where is Henry? I muſt ſee him—muſt caution him (a gun is diſcharged at a diſtance). That's his gun, I ſuppoſe— he is not far then—Poor Henry!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p:
Poor Henry! I like that indeed! What, though he be nobody knows who, there is not a girl in the pariſh that is not ready to pull caps for
him—The Miſs Grundys, genteel as they think themſelves, would be glad to ſnap at him—If he were our own, we could not love him better.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: And he deſerves to be loved—Why, he's as handſome as a peach tree in bloſſom; and his mind is as free from weeds as my favourite carnation bed. But, Thomas, run to the Caſtle, and receive Sir Abel and his ſon.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I wool, I wool—Zo, good day, (bowing.) Let every man make his bow, and behave pratty— that's what I ſay—Miſſus, do'ye ſhew un Sue's letter, woolye? Doye letten ſee how pratty ſhe do write feyther.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Now Tummas is gone, I'll tell you ſuch a ſtory about Mrs. Grundy—But come, ſtep in, you muſt needs be weary; and I am ſure a mug of harveſt beer, ſweetened with a hearty welcome, will refreſh you.

div.head: SCENE II.—Outſide and Gate of the Caſtle.— Servants croſs the Stage, laden with different Packages.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Drabbit it, the wold caſtle 'ull be hardly big enow to hold all thic lumber—Who do come here? A do zeem a comical zoart ov a man—Oh, Abel Handy, I ſuppoze.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel Handy
sp.p: Gently there! mind how you go, Robin.

Zounds and fury! you have killed the whole county, you dog! for you have broke the patent
medicine cheſt, that was to keep them all alive!— Richard, gently!—take care of the grand Archimedian corkſcrews!—Bleſs my ſoul! ſo much to think of! Such wonderful inventions in conception, in concoction, and in completion!
Well, Peter, is the carriage much broke?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Smaſhed all to pieces. I thought as how, Sir, that your infallible axletree would give way.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Confound it, it has compelled me to walk ſo far in the wet, that I declare my waterproof ſhoes are completely ſoaked through.
sp.stage: Exit PETER. Now to take a view with my new-invented glaſs! (pulls out his glaſs.)

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Zarvent, Zur! Zarvent!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: What's that? Oh, good day.—Devil take the fellow!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Thankye, Zur; zame to you wi' all my heart and zoul.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Pray, friend, cou'd you contrive gently to inform me, where I can find one Farmer Aſhfield.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! (laughing loudly.) Excuſe my tittering a bit—but your axing myzel vor I be ſo domm'd zilly (bowing and laughing).—Ah! you ſtare at I beceas I be baſhful and daunted.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: You are very baſhful to be ſure. I declare I'm quite weary.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: If you'll walk into the Caſtle, you may zit down, I dare zay.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: May I, indeed! you are a fellow of extraordinary civility.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: There's no denying it, Zur.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No, I'll ſit here.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What! on the ground? Why, you'll wring your ould withers—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: On the ground—no, I always carry my fear with me (ſpreads a ſmall camp-chair.)— Here I'll ſit and examine the ſurveyor's account of the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dickens and daizeys! what a gentleman you wou'd be to ſhew at a vair!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Silence, fellow, and attend— An account of the caſtle and domain of Sir Philip Blandford, intended to be ſettled as a marriage portion on his daughter, and the ſon of Sir Abel Handy, by Frank Flouriſh, ſurveyor.— Imprimis—The premiſes command an exquiſite view of he iſle of Wight.—Charming! delightful! I don't ſee it though (riſing)—I'll try with my • ew glaſs—my own invention— (he looks through the glaſs) Yes, there I caught it—Ah! now I ſee it plainly—Eh! no—I don't ſee it, do you?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Noa, Zur, I doant—but little zweepy do tell I he can zee a bit out from the top of the chimbley—zoa, an you've a mind to crawl up you may zee un too, he, he!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Thank you—but damn your titter! (reads)—"Fiſh ponds well ſtocked"—That's a good thing, Farmer.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Likely, likely—but I doant think the viſhes do thrive much in theas ponds.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No! Why?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Why, the ponds be always dry i' the zummer; and I be tuold that beant wholeſome vor the little viſhes.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Not very, I believe—Well ſaid ſurveyor! "A cool ſummer-houſe."

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur, quite cool—by reaſon the roof be tumbled in.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Better and better— The whole capable pable of the greateſt improvement.—Come, that ſeems true however—I ſhall have plenty to do, that's one comfort—I'll have ſuch contrivances! I'll have a canal run through my kitchen.—I muſt give this ruſtic ſome idea of my conſequence (aſide). You muſt know, Farmer, you have the honour of converſing with a man who has obtained patents for tweezers, tooth-picks, and tinder-boxes—to a philoſopher who has been conſulted on the Wapping docks and the Graveſend tunnel; and who has now in hand two inventions which will render him immortal—the one is, converting ſaw-duſt into deal boards, and the other is, a plan of cleaning rooms by a ſteam engine—and, Farmer, I mean to give prizes for induſtry—I'll have a ploughing match.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Will you, Zur?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes; for I conſider a healthy young man between the handles of a plough, as one of the nobleſt illuſtrations of the proſperity of Britain.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Faith and troth! there be ſome tightiſh hands in theas parts, I promize ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: And, farmer, it ſhall precede the hymeneal feſtivities—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Nan!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Blockhead! the ploughing match ſhall take place as ſoon as Sir Philip Blandford and his daughter arrive.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Oh, likely, likely!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Abel, I beg to ſay, my maſter will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: And, Sir, I beg to aſk who poſſeſſes the happineſs of being your maſter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Your ſon, Sir, Mr. Robert Handy.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Indeed! and where is Bob?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I left him, Sir, in the belfrey of the church.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: In the belfrey of the church.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: In the belfrey of the church! What was he doing there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why, Sir, the natives were ringing a peal in honour of our arrival—when my maſter finding they knew nothing of the matter, went up to the ſteeple to inſtruct them, and ordered me to proceed to the Caſtle—I have the honour—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Wonderful! My Bob, you muſt know, is an aſtoniſhing fellow!—you have heard of the admirable Crichton, may be? Bob's of the ſame kidney! I contrive, he executes—Sir Abel invenit, Bob fecit. He can do everything—everything!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: All the better vor he. Izay, Zur, as he can turn his hand to everything, pray, in what way med he earn his livelihood?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Earn his livelihood!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur—How do he gain his bread?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Bread! Oh, he can't earn his bread. Bleſs you! he's a genius.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Genius! Drabbit it, I have got a horze o' thic name, but dom' un he'll never work—never.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Egad! here comes my boy Bob!— Eh! no—it is not! no.

div.stage: Enter POSTBOY with a round Hat and Cane.
div.p: Why who the devil are you?

sp.speaker: Poſtb.
sp.p: I am the poſtboy, your Honour; but the Gem'man ſaid I did not know how to drive, ſo he mounted my horſe, and made me get inſide—Here he is.

div.stage: Enter HANDY, jun. with a poſtboy's cap and whip.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Ah, my old Dad, is that you?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Certainly; the only doubt is, if that be you?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh, I was teaching this fellow to drive—Nothing is ſo horrible as people pretending to do what they are unequal to—Give me my hat— That's the way to uſe a whip.

sp.speaker: Poſtb.
sp.p: Sir, you know you have broke the horſes knees all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Huſh, there's a guinea

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: You ſee Bob can do every thing. But, Sir, when you knew I had arrived from Germany, why did you not pay your duty to me in London?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir, I heard you were but four days married, and I would not interrupt your honeymoon.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Four days! oh, you might have come

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I hear you have taken to your arms a ſimple ruſtic, unſophiſticated by faſhionable follies,—a full blown bloſſom of nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: How does it anſwer?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: So, ſo!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Any thorns?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: A few!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I muſt be introduced—where is ihe?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Not within thirty miles; for I don't hear her.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, a pretty behaved tittering friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Zarvent, Zur—no offence I do hope— Could not help tittering a bit at Nelly—when ſhe were zarvent maid wi' I, ſhe had a tightiſh prattle wi' her, that's vor zartain.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh! ſo then my honored Mamma was the ſervant of this tittering gentleman—I ſay, father, perhaps ſhe has not loſt the tightiſh prattle he ſpeaks of.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: My dear boy, come here—Prattle! I ſay, did you ever live next door to a pewterer's?— that's all—you underſtand me—did you ever hear a dozen fire-engines full gallop?—were you ever at Billingſgate in the ſprat ſeaſon?—or—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Nay, don't laugh, Bob.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you think of it too ſeriouſly. The ſtorm, I dare ſay, ſoon blows over.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Soon! You know what a trade wind is, don't you, Bob? why, ſhe thinks no more of the latter end of her ſpeech, than ſhe does of the latter end of her life—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: But I won't be laughed at—I'll knock any man down that laughs!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I beg your pardon—but how in the name of Babel did ſhe wheedle you into matrimony?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, ſhe dealt with me as the devil deals with a witch—humoured me for a time, that I might be her ſlave for ever! I thought I was marrying a notable woman, who would have eaſed my head of part of its burthen: — inſtead of which—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: She has added to its burthen.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: You know, my dear boy, my aim is to make my head uſeful—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: And her aim, I ſuppoſe, is to make it ornamental.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Bob, if you can ſay anything pleaſant, I'll trouble you; if not, do what my wife can't— hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I'll ſhew you what I can do—I'll amuſe you with this native

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Do—do—quiz him—at him, Bob.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I ſay, Farmer, you are a ſet of jolly fellows here, an't you?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur, deadly jolly—excepting when we be otherwiſe, and then we beant.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Play at cricket, don't you?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur; we Hampſhire lads conceat we can bowl a bit or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: And cudgel too, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: At him, Bob.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur, we ſometimes break oon anothers heads by way of being agreeable, and the like o'that.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Underſtand all the guards?
sp.stage: (putting himſelf in an attitude of cudgelling.)

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Can't zay I do, Zur.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What, hit in this way, eh?
sp.stage: (makes a hit at ASHFIELD, which he parries, and hits Young HANDY violently.)

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Noa, Zur, we do hit thic way.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Zounds and fury!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, Bob, he has broke your head.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes; he rather hit me—he ſomehow—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: He did indeed, Bob.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Damn him—The fact is, I am out of practice.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: You need not be, Zur; I'll gi'ye a belly full any day wi' all my heart and ſoul.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No, no, thank you—Farmer, what's your name?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: My name be Tummas Aſhfield—anything to ſay againſt my name?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No, no—Aſhfield! ſhou'd he be the father of my pretty Suſan—Pray, have you a daughter?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, I have—anything to zay againſt ſhe?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No, no; I think her a charming creature.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Do ye faith and troth—Come, that be deadly kind o'ye however—Do you zee, I were frightful ſhe were not agreeable.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh, ſhe's extremely agreeable to me, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I vow, it be quite pratty in you to take notice of Sue. I do hope, Zur, breaking your head will break noa ſquares—She be a coming down to theas parts wi' lady our maid Nelly, as wur—your ſpouſe, Zur.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: The devil ſhe is! that's awkward!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I do hope you'll be kind to Sue when ſhe do come, woolye, Zur?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You may depend on it.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I dareſay you may. Come, Farmey, attend us.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur; wi' all reſpect—Gentlemen, pray walk thic way, and I'll walk before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Now, that's what he calls behaving pretty.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Suſan Aſhfield coming here!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: What, Bob, ſome intrigue, eh?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh fie!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Conſider, Sir, you come here to marry the beautiful and accompliſhed Miſs Blandford— and conſider on the other hand, you have already got a ſlight memorandum of the Farmer's agreeable way.

div.head: SCENE III.—A Grove.
div.stage: (MORRINGTON comes down the ſtage, wrapt in a great coat—He looks about—then at his watch, and whiſtles—which is anſwered.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Here, Gerald! Well, my truſty fellow, is Sir Philip arrived?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, Sir; but hourly expected.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Tell me, how does the Caſtle look?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sadly decayed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hope, Gerald, you were not obſerved.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
I fear otherwiſe, Sir: on the ſkirts of the domain I encountered a ſtripling with his gun;
but I darted into that thicket, and ſo avoided him.

div.stage: (HENRY appears in the back ground, in a ſhooting dreſs, attentively obſerving them.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have you gained any intelligence?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: None: the report that reached us was falſe—The infant certainly died with its mother— Huſh! conceal yourſelf—we are obſerved—this way.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Hold! as a friend, one word!
sp.stage: They exeunt, he follows them and returns.
sp.p: Again they have eſcaped me— The infant died with its mother—This agony of doubt is inſupportable.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Henry, well met.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Have you ſeen ſtrangers?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Two but now have left this place—They ſpoke of a loſt child—My buſy fancy led me to think I was the object of their ſearch—I preſſed forward, but they avoided me.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: No, no; it could not be you; for no one on earth knows but myſelf, and—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Who, Sir Philip Blandford?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: I am ſworn, you know, my dear boy; I am ſolemnly ſworn to ſilence.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
True, my good old friend; and if the knowledge of who I am can only be obtained at
the price of thy perjury, let me for ever remain jgnorant—let the corroding thought ſtill haunt my pillow, croſs me at every turn, and render me inſenſible to the bleſſings of health and liberty— yet, in vain do I ſuppreſs the thought—who am I? why thus abandoned? perhaps the deſpiſed offſpring of guilt—Ah! is it ſo!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Henry, do I deſerve this?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Pardon me, good old man! I'll act more reaſonably—I'll deem thy ſilence mercy.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: That's wiſely ſaid.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yet it is hard to think that the moſt deteſted reptile that Nature forms, or man purſues, has, when be gains his den, a parent's pitying breaſt to ſhelter in; but I—

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Well!—I viſited to-day that young man who was ſo grievouſly bruifed by the breaking of his team.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: That was kindly done, Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I found him ſuffering under extreme torture, yet a ray of joy ſhot from his languid eye—for his medicine was adminiſtered by a father's hand—it was a mother's precious tear that dropt upon his wound—Oh, how I envied him!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Still on the ſame ſubject—I tell thee, if thou art not acknowledged by thy race, why, then become the noble founder of a new one The moſt valuable carnations were once ſeedlings— and the pride of my flower-bed is now a Henry, which, when known, will be envied by every floriſt in Britain—Come with me to the Caſtle for the laſt time.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The laſt time!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Aye, boy; for when Sir Philip arrives, hou muſt avoid him.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Not ſee him! where exiſts the power that ſhall prevent me?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Henry, if you value your own peace of mind—if you value an old man's comfort, avoid the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: I muſt diſſemble with this honeſt creature—Well, I am content.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: That's right—that's right, Henry—Be but thou reſigned and virtuous, and he who cloaths the lily of the field, will be a parent to thee.

div.trailer: THE END OF THE FIRST ACT.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.—A Lodge belonging to the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: HANDY, jun.
sp.p: A SINGULAR ſituation this my old Dad has placed me in; brought me here to marry a woman of faſhion and beauty, while I have been profeſſing and I've a notion feeling the moſt ardent love for the pretty Suſan Aſhfield—Propriety ſays, take Miſs Blandford—Love ſays, take Suſan—Faſhion ſays, take both—but would Suſan conſent to ſuch an arrangement?—and if ſhe refuſed, would I conſent to part with her? Oh time enough to put that queſtion when the previous one is diſpoſed of— (ſeeing DAME) How do you do? How do you do?—Making lace I perceive—Is it a common employment here?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir, nobody can make it in theſe parts but myſelf!—Mrs. Grundy indeed pretends—but, poor woman! ſhe knows no more of it than you do.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Than I do! that's vaſtly well— My dear Madam, I paſſed two months at Mechlin for the expreſs purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You don't do it right—now I can do it much better than that. Give me leave, and I'll ſhew you the true Mechlin method (turns the cuſhion round, kneels down and begins working). Firſt you ſee, ſo—then, ſo—

div.stage: Enter Sir ABEL and Miſs BLANDFORD.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I vow Miſs Blandford, fair as I ever thought you, the air of your native land has given additional luſtre to your charms!— (Aſide.) If my wife looked ſo—Ah! But where can Bob be— you muſt know, Miſs, my ſon is a very clever fellow! you won't find him waſting his time in boyiſh frivolity!—no; you will find him—

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Is that your ſon, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: Yes, that's Bob!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, is he making lace, or is he making love?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Curſe me if I can tell (hits him with his ſtick) Get up you dog! don't you ſee Miſs Blandford?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Zounds! how unlucky! Ma'am, your moſt obedient ſervant (endeavours to hide the work). Curſe the cuſhion!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Oh! he has ſpoiled my lace!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p:
Huſh! I'll make you a thouſand yards another time—You ſee, Ma'am, I was explaining to this good woman—what—what need
not be explained again—Admirably handſome by Heaven!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Is not ſhe, Bob?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: In your journey from the coaſt, I conclude you took London in your way? Huſh!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir, I could not ſo ſoon venture into the beau monde, a ſtranger juſt arrived from Germany—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: The very reaſon—the moſt faſhionable introduction poſſible! but I perceive, Sir, you have here imitated other German importations, and only reſtored to us our native excellence.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Sir, I am eager to ſeize my birth-right, the pure and envied immunities of an Engliſh woman!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Then I truſt, Madam, you will be patriot enough to agree with me, that a • a nation is poor, whoſe only wealth is importation—that therefore the humble native artiſt may ever hope to obtain from his countrymen thoſe foſtering ſmiles, without which genius muſt ſicken and induſtry decay. But it requires no valet de place to conduct you through the purlieus of faſhion, for now the way of the world is, for every one to purſue their own way, and following the faſhion is differing as much as poſſible from the reſt of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: But ſurely, Sir, there is ſome diſtinguiſhing feature by which the votaries of faſhion are known?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes; but that varies extremely— ſometimes faſhionable celebrity depends on a high waiſt—ſometimes on a low carriage—ſometimes on high play, and ſometimes on low breeding—laſt winter it reſted ſolely on green peas!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Green peas!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Green peas!—that Lady was the moſt enchanting who could bring the greateſt quantity of green peas to her table at Chriſtmas! the ſtruggle was tremendous! Mrs. Rowley Powley had the beſt of it by five pecks and a half, but it having been unfortunately proved, that at her ball there was room to dance and eat conveniently—that n • lady received a black eye, and no coachman was killed, the thing was voted decent and comfortable, and ſcouted accordingly.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Is comfort then incompatible with faſhion?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Certainly!—Comfort in high life would be as prepoſterous as a lawyer's bag crammed with truth, or his wig decorated with coquelicot ribbons! No—it is not comfort and ſelection that is ſought, but numbers and confuſion! So that a faſhionable party reſembles Smithfield market, only a good one when plentifully ſtocked—and ladies are reckoned by the ſcore like ſheep, and their huſbands by droves like horned cattle!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Ha, ha! and the converſation—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh! like the aſſembly—confuſed, vapid, and abundant; as How do, Ma'am!—no accident at the door?—he, he!—Only my carriage broke to pieces!—I hope you had not your pocket picked!—Won't you ſit down to faro?—"Have you many to-night?" —"A few, about ſix hundred!"—Were you at Lady Overall's?—Oh yes; a delicious crowd and plenty of peas, he, he!—and thus runs the faſhionable race.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p:
Yes; and a precious run it is—full gallop all the way: firſt they run on—then their fortune is run through—then bills are run up—
then they are run hard—then they've a run of luck —then they run out, and then they run away!— But I'll forgive faſhion all it's follies in conſideration of one of its bleſſed laws.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What may that be?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: That huſband and wife muſt never be ſeen together.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Miſs Blandford, your father expects you.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall find him more compoſed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Is Sir Philip ill?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: His ſpirits are extremely depreſſed, and ſince we arrived here this morning his dejection has dreadfully increaſed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: But I hope we ſhall be able to laugh away deſpondency.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Sir, if you are pleaſed to conſider my eſteem as an object worthy your poſſeſſion, I know of no way of obtaining it ſo certain as by your ſhewing every attention to my dear father.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dame! Dame! ſhe be come!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Who? Suſan! our dear Suſan

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees—zo come along—Oh, Sir Abel! Lady Nelly! your ſpouſe—do order you to go to her directly!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Order! you miſtake—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No, he don't—ſhe generally preſers that word.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Adieu! Sir Abel.

div.stage: Exeunt Miſs BLANDFORD and HANDY, jun.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh! if my wife had ſuch a pretty way with her mouth!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And how does Suſan look?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: That's what I do want to know, zoa come along—Woo ye though—Miſſus, let's behave pratty—Zur, if you pleaze, Dame and I will let you walk along wi' us.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: How condeſcending! Oh, you are a pretty behaved fellow!

div.head: SCENE II. Farmer ASHFIELD'S Kitchen.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: My dear home, thrice welcome! what gratitude I feel to your Ladyſhip for this indulgence.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: That's right, child!

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: And I am ſure you partake my pleaſure in again viſiting a place where you received every protection and kindneſs my parents could ſhew you, for I remember while you lived with my father—

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Child! don't put your memory to any fatigue on my account—you may transfer the remembrance of who I was, to aid your more perfect recollection of who I am.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Lady Handy!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: That's right, child! I am not angry.

sp.speaker: Suſan
sp.p: How luxuriantly the honeyſuckle has grown that I planted—Ah! I ſee my dear father and mother coming through the garden.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Oh! now I ſhall be careſſed to death but I muſt endure the ſhock of their attentions.

div.stage: Enter Farmer and Dame with Sir ABEL.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: My dear Suſan!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: My ſweet child! give me a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Hald thee! Feyther firſt though—Well, I be as mortal glad to zee thee as never war—and how be'st thee? and how do thee like Lunnun town?—it be a deadly lively place I be tuold.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Is not ſhe a ſweet girl?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: That ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Does it occur to any one preſent that Lady Handy is in the room?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, Lud! I'm ſure, my dear wife, I never forget that you are in the room.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Drabbit it! I overlooked Lady Nelly, ſure enow; but conſider, there be zome difference between thee and our own Suſan! I be deadly glad to zee thee however.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: So am I, Lady Handy!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Don't ye take it unkind I ha'nt a buſs'd thee yet—meant no ſlight indeed

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Oh! ſhocking!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: No harm I do hope, Zur.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: None at all.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: But daſh it, Lady Nelly, what do make thee paint thy vace all over we rud ochre zoo? Be it vor thy ſpouſe to knaw thee?—that be the way I do knaw my ſheep.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: The flocks of faſhion are all marked ſo, Farmer.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Likely! Drabbit it! thee do make a tightiſh kind of a Ladyſhip zure enow.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That you do, my Lady! you remember the old houſe?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Aye; and all about it, doant ye? Nelly! my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Oh! I'm quite ſhock'd—Suſan, child! prepare a room where I may dreſs before I proceed to the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I don't ſee Suſan—I ſay, Dad! is that my Mamma?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes—ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: A fine girl upon my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Lady Handy.
sp.p: Fine girl indeed! Is this behaviour?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh! beg pardon, moſt honoured parent (ſhe curtſies)—that's a damned bad curtſey. I can teach you to make a much better curtſey than that!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: You teach me, that am old enough to—hem!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh! that toſs of the head was very bad indeed—Look at me!—That's the thing!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Am I to be inſulted? Sir Abel, you know I ſeldom condeſcend to talk.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Don't ſay ſo, my Lady; you wrong yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: But when I do begin, you know not where it will end.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Indeed I do not

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: I inſiſt on receiving all poſſible reſpect from your ſon.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: And you ſhall have it, my dear girl!—Madam, I mean.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: I vow I am agitated to that degree— Sir Abel, my fan!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes, my dear—Bob, look here, a little contrivance of my own. While others carry ſwords, and ſuch like dreadful weapons in their canes, I more gallantly carry a fan (removes the head of his cane and draws out a fan), a pretty thought, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Some difference between thic ſtick and mine, beant there, Zur?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes, there is— (to Lady H.) Do you call that fanning yourſelf (taking the fan). My dear Ma'am, this is the way to manoeuvre a fan.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall find (to HANDY, jun.) I have power enough to make you repent this behaviour —ſeverely repent it—Suſan!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Bravo! paſſion becomes her—She does that vaſtly well.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes; practice makes perfect.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Did your Ladyſhip call?—Heavens! Mr. Handy!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Huſh! my angel! be compoſed! that letter will explain (giving a letter, noticed by ASHFIELD). Lady Handy wiſhes to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, Robert!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: At preſent my love, no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: What were you ſaying, Sir, to that young woman?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Nothing particular, Sir. Where is Lady Handy going.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: To dreſs.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſhe has found out the uſe of money.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes; I'll do her the juſtice to ſay ſhe encourages trade.—Why, do you know, Bob, my beſt coal-pit won't find her in white muſlins—round her neck hangs a hundred acres at leaſt; my nobleſt oaks have made wigs for her; my fat oxen have dwindled into Dutch pugs, and white mice; my India bonds are tranſmuted into ſhawls and otto of roſes; and a magnificent manſion has ſhrunk into a diamond ſnuff-box.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the folks be all got together, and the ploughs be ready—and—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: We are coming.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Ploughs!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes, Bob, we are going to have a grand agricultural meeting.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: If I could but find a man able to manage my new invented curricle plough, none of them would have a chance.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My dear Sir, if there be anything on earth I can do, it is that.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I rather fancy I can plough better than any man in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo! What a clever fellow he is—I ſay, Bob, if you would—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; I can't condeſcend.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Condeſcend! why not?—much more creditable, let me tell you, than galloping a maggot for a thouſand, or eating a live cat, or any other faſhionable achievement.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: So it is—Egad! I will—I'll carry off the prize of induſtry.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: But ſhould you loſe, Bod.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I loſe! that's vaſtly well!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: True, with my curricle plough you could hardly fail.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: With my ſuperior ſkill, Dad— Then, I ſay, how the newſpapers will teem with the account.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: That univerſal genius, Handy, junior, with a plough—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Stop—invented by that ingenious machiniſt, Handy, ſenior.—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Gained the prize againſt the firſt huſbandmen in Hampſhire—Let our Bond-ſtreet butterflies emulate the example of Handy, junior.—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: And let old City grubs cultivate the field of ſcience, like Handy, ſenior—Ecod, I am ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Lady Handy
sp.p: Sir Abel.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Ah! there comes a damper.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Courage, you have many reſources of happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Have I? I ſhould be very glad to know them.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: In the firſt place you poſſeſs an excellent temper.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: So much the worſe; for if I had a bad one, I ſhould be the better able to conquer hers.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You enjoy good health—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: So much the worſe; for if I were ill ſhe wouldn't come near me.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Then you are rich—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: So much the worſe; for had I been poor ſhe would not have married me. But I ſay, Bob, if you gain the prize, I'll have a patent for my plough.

sp.speaker: Lady Handy
sp.p: Sir Abel, I ſay.—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Father, could not you get a patent for ſtopping that ſort of noiſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: If I could, what a ſale it would have!—No, Bob, a patent has been obtained for the only thing that will ſilence her—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Aye—What's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: A coffin! huſh!—I'm coming my dear.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

div.head: SCENE III.—A Parlour in ASHFIELD's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I tell ye, I zee'd un gi' Suſan 2 letter, an' I dan't like it a bit.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Nor I: if ſhame ſhould come to the poor child—I ſay, Tummas, what would Mrs. Grundy ſay then?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dom Mrs. Grundy; what wou'd my poor wold heart zay? but I be bound it be all innocence.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ah! Henry, we have not ſeen thee at home ail day.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: And I do zomehow fanzie things dan't go zo clever when thee'rt away from farm.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: My mind has been greatly agitated.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well, won't thee go and zee the ploughing match?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Tell me, will not thoſe who obtain prizes be introduced to the Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, and feaſted in the great hall.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: My good friend, I wiſh to become a candidate.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: You, Henry!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: It is time I exerted the faculties heaven has beſtowed on me; and though my heavy fate cruſhes the proud hopes this heart conceives, ſtill let me prove myſelf worthy of the place Providence has aſſigned me.— (Aſide) Should I ſucceed, it will bring me to the preſence of that man, who (I know not why) ſeems the dictator of my fate.— (To them) Will you furniſh me with the means?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Will I!—Thou ſhalt ha' the beſt plough in the pariſh—I wiſh it were all gould for thy zake— and better cattle there can't be noowhere.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Thanks, my good friend—my benefactor —I have little time for preparation—So receive my gratitude, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: A bleſſing go with thee!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I zay, Henry, take Jolly, and Smiler, and Captain, but dan't ye take thic lazy beaſt Genius —I'll be ſhot if having vive load an acre on my wheat land cou'd pleaſe me more.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Tummas, here comes Suſan reading the letter.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: How pale ſhe do look, dan't ſhe?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ah! poor thing!—If—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Hauld thy tongue, woolye?

sp.speaker: Suſan
sp.p: Is it poſſible? Can the man to whom I've given my heart write thus:— I am compelled to marry Miſs Blandford; but my love for my Suſan is unalterable—I hope ſhe will not, for an act of neceſſity, ceaſe to think with tenderneſs on her faithful Robert.—Oh man! ungrateful man! it is from our boſoms alone you derive your power; how cruel then to uſe it, in fixing in thoſe boſoms endleſs ſorrow and deſpair. —"Still think with tenderneſs"—Baſe, diſhonorable inſinuation—He might have allowed me to eſteem him.
sp.stage: Locks up the letter in a box on the table, and exit weeping.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Poor thing!—What can be the matter— She lock'd up the letter in thic box, and then burſted into tears

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Yes, Tummas, ſhe locked it in that box ſure enough
sp.stage: (ſhakes a bunch of keys that hangs at her ſide).

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What be doing, Dame? what be doing?

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: Nothing; I was only touching theſe keys.

div.stage: (They look at the box and keys ſignificantly)

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: A good tightiſh bunch!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Yes; they are of all ſizes

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Indeed!—Well—Eh!—Dame, why dan't ye ſpeak; thou can'ſt chatter vaſt enow zometimes.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Nay, Tummas—I dare ſay—if—you know beſt—but I think I could find—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well, Eh!—you can juſt try you knaw (greatly agitated) You can try, juſt vor the vun on't; but mind, dan't ye make a noiſe (ſhe opens it). Why, thee hasn't open'd it?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Nay, Tummas, you told me!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Did I?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: There's the letter!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well, why do ye gi't to I?—I dan't want it, I'm zure (taking it—he turns it over—ſhe eyes it eagerly—he is about to open it)—She's coming! ſhe's coming!(he conceals the letter, they tremble violently.) No, ſhe's gone into t'other room (they hang their heads dejectedly, then look at each other). What mun that feyther and mother be doing that do bluſh and tremble at their own dater's coming (weeps). Dang it, has ſhe deſarv'd it of us—Did ſhe ever deceive us?—Were ſhe not always the moſt open-hearted, dutiſulleſt, kindeſt—and thee to goa like a dom'd ſpy and open her box, poor thing?—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Nay, Tummas—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: You did—I zaw you do it myzel—you look like a thief, now—you doe—Huſh!—no— Dame—here be the letter—I won't reead a word on't, put it where thee wound it, and as there vound it.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: With all my heart
sp.stage: (ſhe returns the letter to the box).

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p:
Now I can wi' pleaſure hug my wold wife, and look my child in the vace again—I'll call her and ax her about it; and if ſhe dan't ſpeak without diſguiſement, I'll be bound to
be ſhot—Dame, be the colour of ſheame off my face yet?—I never zeed thee look ugly before— Suſan, my dear Sue, come here abit, woolye?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Yes, my dear father.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Sue, we do wiſh to gi' thee a bit of admoniſhing and parent-like conzultation.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: I hope I have ever attended to your admonitions.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, bleſs thee, I do believe thee haſt, lamb; but we all want our memories jogg'd abit, or why elſe do parſon preach us all to ſleep every Zunday—Zo thic be the topic—Dame and I, Sue, did zee a letter gi'd to thee, and thee—burſted into tears, and lock'd un up in thic box—and then Dame and I—we—that's all.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: My dear father, if I concealed the contents of that letter from your knowledge, it was becauſe I did not wiſh your heart to ſhare in the pain mine feels.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dang it, didn't I tell thee zoo?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Nay, Tummas, did I ſay otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Believe me, my dear parents, my heart never gave birth to a thought my tongue feared to utter.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: There, the very words I zaid!

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: If you wiſh to ſee the letter I will ſhew it to you

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Here's a key will open it.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Drabbit it, hold thy tongue, thou wold fool! (aſide.) No, Suſan, I'll not zee it—I'll believe my child.

sp.speaker: Suſsan.
sp.p:
You ſhall not find your confidence illplaced —it is true the gentleman has declared he
loved me; it is equally true that declaration was not unpleaſing to me—Alas! it is alſo true, that his letter contains ſentiments diſgraceful to himſelf, and inſulting to me!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Drabbit it, if I'd knaw'd that, when we were cudgelling abit, I wou'd ha' lapt my ſtick about his ribs pratty tightiſh, I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Pray, father, don't you reſent his conduct to me.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What, mayn't I leather un abit?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, no! I have the ſtrongeſt reaſons to the contrary!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well, Sue, I won't—I'll behave as pratty as I always do—but it be time to go to the green, and zee the fine zights—How I do hate the noiſe of thic dom'd bunch of keys—But bleſs thee, my child—dan't forget that vartue to ayoung woman be vor all the world like—like—Dang it, I ha' gotten it all in my head; but zomehow—I can't talk it— but vartue be to a young woman what corn be to a blade o'wheat, do ye zee; for while the corn be there it be glorious to the eye, and it be call'd the ſtaff of life; but take that treaſure away, and what do remain? why naught but this worthleſs ſtraw, that man and beaſt do tread upon.

div.head: SCENE IV.—An extenſive View of a cultivated Country—A ploughed Field in the centre, in which are ſeen ſix different Ploughs and Horſes—At one ſide a bandſome Tent—a number of country People aſſembled.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Make way! make way for the gentry; and do ye hear, behave pratty, as I do—Dang thee ſtond back, or I'll knack thee down, I wool.

div.stage: Enter Sir ABEL and Miſs BLANDFORD with Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It is very kind of you to honour our ruſtic feſtivities with your preſence.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Abel, where is your ſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: What, Bob? Oh, you'll ſee him preſently. (nodding ſignificantly). Here are the prize medals; and if you will condeſcent to preſent them. I'm ſure they'll be worn with additional pleaſure. —I ſay, you'll ſee Bob preſently—Well, Farmer, is it all over?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ecs, Zur; the acres be plough'd and the ground judg'd; and the young lads be coming down to receive their reward—Heartily welcome, Miſs, to your native land; hope you be as pleas'd to zee we as we be to zee you, and the like o'that.—Mortal beautizome to be zure—I declare, Miſs, it do make I quite warm zomehow to look at ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Now you'll ſee Bob—now my dear boy, Bob—here he comes

div.stage: Enter HENRY and two young Huſhandmen.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: 'Tis he, he has don't—Dang you all, why dan't ye ſhout? Huzza!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, zounds, where's Bob?—I don't ſee Bob—Bleſs me, what has become of Bob and my plough?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well, Henry, there be the prize, and there be the fine Lady that will gi'it thee.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Tell me who is that lovely creature?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: The dater of Sir Philip Blandford.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What exquiſite ſweetneſs! Ah! ſhould the father but reſemble her, I ſhall have but little to ſear from his ſeverity!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Miſs, thic be the young man that ha got'n the guolden prize.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: This; I always thought ploughmen were coarſe, vulgar creatures, but he ſeems handſome and diffident.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, quite pratty behaved—it were I that teach'd un.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Henry!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: And your family?
sp.stage: (HENRY, in an agony of grief, turns away, ſtrikes his forebead, and leans on the ſhoulder of ASHFIELD.)

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Madam, I beg pardon, but nobody knows about his parentage; and when it is mentioned, poor boy! he takes on ſadly—He has lived at our houſe ever ſince we had the farm, and we have had an allowance for him—ſmall enough to be ſure—but, good lad! he was always welcome to ſhare what we had.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I am ſhocked at my imprudence.— (To HENRY) Pray pardon me; I would not inſult an enemy, much leſs one I am inclined to admire — (giving her hand, then withdraws it)—to eſteem —you ſhall go to the Caſtle—my father ſhall protect you.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Generous creature! to merit his eſteem is the fondeſt wiſh of my heart—to be your ſlave, the proudeſt aim of my ambition!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Receive your merited reward (he kneels —ſhe places the medal round his neck—the ſame to the others).

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: I can't ſee Bob; pray, Sir, do you happen to know what is become of my Bob?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Did not you ſee a remarkable clever plough, and a young man—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: At the beginning of the conteſt, I obſerved a gentleman; his horſes, I believe, were unruly, but my attention was too much occupied to allow me to notice more.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: How dare you laugh?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: That's Bob's voice!

div.stage: Enter HANDY, jun. in a ſmock frock, cocked hat, and a piece of a plough in his hand.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Dare to laugh again, and I'll knock you down with this—Ugh! how infernally hot

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, Bob, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I don't know where I've been.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: And what have you got in your hand?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What? All I could keep of your nonſenſical ricketty plough

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Come, none of that, Sir.—Don't abuſe my plough to cover your ignorance, Sir; where is it, Sir? and where are my famous Leiceſterſhire horſes, Sir?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Where! ha, ha, ha! I'll tell you as nearly as I can, ha, ha! What's the name of the next county?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: It be called Wiltſhire, Zur.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Then, Dad, upon the niceſt calculation I am able to make, they are at this moment engaged in the very patriotic act of ploughing Saliſbury plain, ha, ha! I ſaw them fairly over that hill, full gallop, with the curricle plough at their heels.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha! a good one, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p:
But never mind father, you muſt again ſet your invention to work, and I my toilet —rather a deranged figure to appear before a lady
in (fiddles). Hey dey! What, are you going to dance?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ecs, Zur; I ſuppoſe you can ſheake a leg abit?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I ſancy I can dance every poſſible ſtep, from the pas ruſe to the war dance of the Catabaws.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Likely—I do hope, Miſs, you'll join your honeſt neighbours; they'll be deadly hurt an you won't gig it a bit wi'un.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Bob's an excellent dancer.

sp.speaker: Miſs. B.
sp.p: I dare ſay he is, Sir; but on this occa ſion, I think I ought to dance with the young man who gained the prize—I think it would be moſt pleaſant—moſt proper, I mean; and I am glad you agree with me—So, Sir, if you'll accept my hand

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Very pleaſantly ſettled upon my ſoul —Bob, won't you dance?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I dance!—No, I'll look at them— I'll quietly look on.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Egad, now as my wife's away, I'll try to find a pretty girl and make one among them.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: That's hearty—Come, Dame, hang the rheumatics—Now, lads and laſſes, behave pratty, and ſtrike up.

div.stage: (HANDY, jun. looks on a little, and then begins to move his legs—then daſhes into the midſt of the dance, and endeavours to imitate every one oppoſite to him; then being exhauſted, he leaves the dance, ſeizes the fiddle, and plays till the curtain drops).

div.trailer: THE END OF THE SECOND ACT.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.—An Apartment in the Caſtle.
div.stage: Sir PHILIP BLANDFORD diſcovered on a couch, reading, SERVANTS attending.

sp.speaker: Sir PHILIP.
sp.p: Is not my daughter yet returned?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Diſpatch a ſervant to her.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the old gardener is below, and aſks to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Admit him inſtantly, and leave me.—
sp.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, who bows, then looking at Sir PHILIP claſps his hands together and weeps.
sp.p: Does this deſolation affect the old man? Come near me—Time has laid a lenient hand on thee—

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Oh, my dear maſter! can twenty years have wrought the change I ſee?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No (ſtriking his breaſt); 'tis the canker here that hath withered up my trunk;—but are we ſecure from obſervation?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Then tell me, does the boy live?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: He does; and is as fine a youth—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No comments.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: We named him—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Be dumb! let me not hear his name, Has care been taken he may not blaſt me with his preſence?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: It has; and he cheerfully complied.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Enough! Never ſpeak of him more. Have you removed every dreadful veſtige from the fatal chamber? (EVERGREEN heſitates.) O ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: My dear maſter! I confeſs my want of duty. Alas! I had not courage to go there.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Nay, ſorgive me! wiſer than I have ſelt ſuch terrors!—The apartments have been careſully locked up—the keys not a moment from my poſſeſſion—here they are.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Then the taſk remains with me. Dreadful thought! I can well pardon thy fears, old man—O! could I wipe from my memory that hour, when—

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Huſh! your daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Leave me—we'll ſpeak anon.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Dear father! I came the moment I heard you wiſhed to ſee me.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My good child, thou art the ſole ſupport that props my feeble life. I fear my wiſh for thy company deprives thee of much pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh no! What pleaſure can be equal to that of giving you happineſs? Am I not rewarded in ſeeing your eyes beam with pleaſure on me?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: 'Tis the pale reflection of the luſtre I ſee ſparkling there. My love! did you enjoy the ſcenes you beheld?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Greatly. How ſtrongly they contraſt with thoſe we witneſſed abroad!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: True. Happy country! which, in the midſt of direful war can draw out its ruſtic train to join the feſtive dance, as ſecurely as if peace again had bleſſed the world!—But tell me, did your lover gain the prize?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes, papa.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Few men of his rank—

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh! you mean Mr. Handy?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: No; he did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Then, who did you mean?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Did you ſay lover? I—I miſtook—No —a young man called Henry obtained the prize!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: And how did Mr. Handy ſucceed?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh, it was ſo ridiculous! I will tell you, papa, what happened to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: To Mr. Handy?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes; as ſoon as the conteſt was over Henry preſented himſelf; I was ſurprized at ſeeing a young man ſo handſome and elegant as Henry is—then I placed the medal round Henry's neck, and I was told that poor Henry—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Henry!—So, my love! this is your account of Mr. Robert Handy?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes, papa—no, papa—he came afterwards, dreſſed ſo ridiculouſly that even Henry could not help ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Henry again!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Then we had a dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Of courſe you danced with your lover?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes, papa.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: How does Mr. Handy dance?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh! he did not dance till—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: You danced with your lover?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes—No, papa!—Somebody ſaid (I don't know who) that I ought to dance with Henry, becauſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Still Henry! Oh! ſome ruſtic boy. My dear child, you talk as if you loved this Henry.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh! no, papa—and I am certain he don't love me.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes, papa; for when he touched my hand, he trembled as if I terrified him; and inſtead of looking at me as you do, who I am ſure love me, when our eyes met, he withdrew his and caſt them on the ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: And theſe are the reaſons which make you conclude he does not love you?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes, papa.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: And probably you could adduce proof equally convincing that you don't love him?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh yes—quite; for in the dance he ſometimes paid attention to other young women, and I was ſo angry with him! Now, you know, papa, I love you—and I am ſure I ſhould not have been angry with you, had you done ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: But one queſtion more—Do you think Mr. Handy loves you?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I have never thought about it, papa.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Yes; I knew I ſhould convince you.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Oh, Love! malign and ſubtle tyrant, how falſely art thou painted blind! 'Tis thy votaries are ſo; for what but blindneſs can prevent their ſeeing thy poiſoned ſhaft, which is for ever doomed to rankle in the victim's heart.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh! now I am certain I am not in love; for I feel no rankling at my heart. I feel the ſofteſt, ſweeteſt ſenſation I ever experienced. But, papa, you muſt come to the lawn. I don't-know why, but to-day Nature ſeems enchanting; the birds ſing more ſweetly, and the flowers give more perfume.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Such was the day my youthful ſancy pictured! How did it cloſe?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I promifed Henry your protection.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Indeed! that was much. Well, I will ſee your ruſtic here. This infant paſſion muſt be cruſhed. Poor wench! ſome artleſs boy has caught thy infant fancy!—Thy arm, my child!

div.head: SCENE II.—A Lawn before the C ſile.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well! here thee'rt going to make thy bow to Sir Philip. I zay, if he ſhould take a fancy to thee, thou'lt come to farm and zee us zometimes, wo'tn't Henry?

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Tell me, is that Sir Philip Blandford who leans on that lady's arm?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I don't know, by reaſon d'ye zee I never zeed'un. Well, good bye! I declare thee doz look quite grand wi' thic golden prize about thy neck, vor all the world like the lords in their ſtars, that do come to theas pearts to pickle their ſkins in the zale zea ocean! Good b'ye, Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: He approaches! Why this agitation? I wiſh, yet dread, to meet him.

div.stage: Enter SIR PHILIP and Miſs BLANDFORD, attended.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: The joy your tenantry diſplay at ſeeing you again muſt be truly grateful to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No, my child; for I feel I do not merit it. Alas! I can ſee no orphans cloathed with my beneficence, no anguiſh aſſuaged by my care.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Then I am ſure my dear father wiſhes to ſhew his kind intentions. So I will begin by placing one under his protection
sp.stage: (goes up the ſtage and leads down HENRY. Sir PHILIP, on ſecing him, ſtarts, then becomes greatly agitated).

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! do my eyes deceive me? No, it muſt be him! Such was the face his father wore!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Spake you of my father?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: His preſence brings back recollections which drive me to madneſs! How came he here? Who have I to curſe for this?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Your daughter.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, tell me! on my knees I aſk it! do my parents live? Bleſs me with my father's name, and my days ſhall paſs in active gratitude—
my nights in prayers for you. (Sir PHILIP views him with ſevere contempt.) Do not mock my miſery! Have you a heart?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes; of marble. Cold and obdurate to the world—ponderous and painſul to myſelf —Quit my ſight for ever!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Go, Henry, and ſave me from my father's curſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I obey: cruel as the command is, I obey it—I ſhall often look at this (touching the medal) and think on the bliſsful moment when your hand placed it there.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! tear it from his breaſt.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sooner take my life! It is the firſt honour I have earned, and it is no mean one; for it aſſigns me the firſt rank among the ſons or induſtry! This is my claim to the ſweet rewards of honeſt labour! This will give me competence, nay more, enable me to deſpiſe your tyranny!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Raſh boy, mark! Avoid me, and be ſecure—Repeat this intruſion, and my vengeance ſhall purſue thee—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I defy its power!—You are in England, Sir, where the man, who bears about him an upright heart, bears a charm too potent for tyranny to humble. Can your frown wither up my youthful vigour? No!—Can your malediction diſturb the ſlumbers of a quiet conſcience? No! Can your breath ſtifle in my heart the adoration it feels for that pitying angel? Oh, no!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Wretch! you ſhall be taught the difference between us!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
I feel it now! proudly feel it!—You hate the man that never wronged you—I could
love the man that injures me—You meanly triumph o'er a worm—I make a giant tremble.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Take him from my ſight! Why am I not obeyed?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Henry, if you wiſh my hate ſhould not accompany my father's, inſtantly begone.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, pity me!

div.stage: (Miſs BLANFORD looks after him—Sir PHILIP, exhauſted, leans on his Servants).

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Supported by my ſervants! I thought I had a daughter!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: O, you have, my father! one that loves you better than her life!
Leave us.

div.p: Emma, if you feel, as I fear you do, love for that youth—mark my words! When the dove woos for its mate the ravenous kite; when Nature's fixed antipathies mingle in ſweet concord, then and not till then, hope to be united.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Have you not promiſed me the diſpoſal of your hand?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Alas! my father! I didn't then know the difficulty of obedience!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Hear, then, the reaſons why I demand compliance. You think I hold theſe rich eſtates—Alas, the ſhadow only, not the ſubſtance.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Explain, my father!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
When I left my native country, I leſt it with a heart lacerated by every wound that the falſehood of others or my own conſcience could inflict. Hateful to myſelf, I became the victim of diſſipation—I ruſhed to the gaming table, and ſoon became the dupe of villains.—My ample fortune
was loſt; I detected one in the act of ſraud, and having brought him to my feet, he confeſſed a plan had been laid for my ruin; that he was but an humble inſtrument; for that the man who, by his ſuperior genius, ſtood poſſeffed of all the mortgages and ſecurities I had given, was one Mortington.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I have heard your name him before. Did you not know this Morrington?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No; he, like his deeds, avoided the light—Ever dark, ſubtle, and myſterious. Collecting the ſcattered remnant of my fortune, I wandered wretched and deſolare, till, in a peaceful village, I firſt beheld thy mother, humble in birth, but exalted in virtue. The morning after our marriage ſhe received a packet, containing theſe words: The reward of virtuous love, preſented by a repentant villain; and which alſo contained bills and notes to the high amount of ten thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: And no name?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: None; nor could I ever gueſs at the generous donor. I need not tell thee what my heart ſuffered when death deprived me of her. Thus circumſtanced, this good man, Sir Abel Handy, propoſed to unite our families by marriage; and in conſideration of what he termed the honor of our alliance, agreed to pay off every incumbrance on my eſtates, and ſettle them as a portion on you and his ſon. Yet ſtill another wonder remains.—When I arrive, I find no claim whatever has been made, either by Morrington or his agents. What am I to think? Can Morrington have periſhed, and with him his large claims to my property? Or, does he withhold the blow, to make it fall more heavily?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange! very myſterious! But my father has not told me what misfortune led him to leave his native country.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: May I not know it?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Oh! never, never, never!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: I will not aſk it—Be compoſed—Let me wipe away thoſe drops of anguiſh from your brow.—How cold your check is! My father, the evening damps will harm you—Come in—I will be all you wiſh—indeed I will.

div.head: SCENE III.—An Apartment in the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Was ever anything ſo unlucky! Henry to come to the Caſtle and meet Sir Philip. He ſhould have conſulted me; I ſhall be blamed—but, thank heaven, I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: I will be treated with reſpect.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: You ſhall, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: But how! but how! Sir Abel, I repeat it.—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: For the fiftieth time.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Your ſon conducts himſelf with an inſolence I won't endure; but you are ruled by him, you have no will of your own.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I have not indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: How contemptible!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p:
Why, my dear, this is the caſe—I am like the aſs in the fable; and if I am doomed to
carry a pack-ſaddle, it is not much matter who drives me.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: To yield your power to thoſe the law allows you to govern!—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Is very weak indeed.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Lady Handy, your very humble ſervant; I heartily congratulate you, Madam, on your marriage this worthy gentleman—Sir, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: Abel
sp.p: Not before 'tis wanted.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Aye, my Lady; this match makes up for the imprudence of your firſt.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Eh! What!—what's that—Eh! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: I mean, Sir—that Lady Handy's former huſband—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Former huſband!—Why, my dear, I never knew—Eh!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: A mumbling old blockhead!—Didn't you Sir Abel? Yes; I was rather married many years ago; but my huſband went abroad and died.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Died, did he?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; he was a ſervant in the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Indeed! So he died—poor fellow!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: What, you are ſure he died, are you?

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Don't you hear?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Poor fellow! neglected perhaps—had I known it, he ſhould have had the beſt advice money could have got.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: You ſeem ſorry.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why you would not have me pleaſed at the death of your huſband, would you?—a good kind of man!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Yes; a faithful fellow—rather ruled his wife too ſeverely.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Did he? (apart to EVERGREEN.) Pray do you happen to recollect his manner?— Could you juſt give a hint of the way he had?

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Do you want to tyrannize over my poor tender heart?—'Tis too much!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Bleſs me! Lady Handy is ill—Salts! ſalts!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: Here are ſalts, or aromatic vinegar, or eſſence of—

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Any—any.

sp.speaker: Sir bel.
sp.p: Bleſs me, I can't find the key!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Pick the lock

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It can't b • picked, it is a patent lock.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: The br •• k i • o • en, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It can't be broke open—it is a contrivance of my own—you ſee, here comes a horizontal bolt, which acts upon a ſpring, therefore—

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: I may die while you are deſcribing a horizontal bolt. Do you think you ſhall cloſe your eyes for a week for this?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What has occaſioned this diſturbance?

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Aſk that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Sir, I am accuſed—

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Convicted! convicted!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Well, I will not argue with you about words—becauſe I muſt bow to your ſuperior practice —But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Pſhaw! (apart.) Lady Handy, ſome of your people were inquiring for you.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir. Come, Sir Abel.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady—I ſay (to EVERGREEN), cou'dn't you give me a hint of the way he had—

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir Abel!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Coming, my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: So! you have well obeyed my orders in keeping this Henry from my preſence.

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: I was not to blame, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Has Farmer Aſhfield left the Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Send him hither.

div.p: That boy muſt be driven far, far from my ſight— but where?—no matter! the world is large enough.
—Come hither. I believe you hold a farm of mine?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur, I do, at your zarvice.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I hope a profitable one?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Zometimes it be, Zur. But thic year it be all t'other way as 'twur—but I do hope as our landlords have a tightiſh big lump of the good, they'll be zo kind hearted as to take a little bit of the bad.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: It is but reaſonable—I conclude then you are in my debt.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur, I be—at your zarvice.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: How much!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Sir, I do owe ye a hundred and fifty pounds—at your zarvice.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Which you can't pay?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Not a varthing, Zur—at your zarvice.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Well, I am willing to give you every indulgence.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Be you, Zur? that be deadly kind. Dear heart! it will make my auld Dame quite young again, and I don't think helping a poor man will do your Honour's health any harm—I don't indeed, Zur—I had a thought of ſpeaking to your worſhip about it—but then thinks I, the gentleman mayhap be one of thoſe that do like to do a good turn; and not have a word zaid about it—zo, Zur, if you had not mentioned what I owed you, I am zure ! never ſhould—ſhould not indeed, Zur.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Nay, I will wholly acquit you of the debt, on condition—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: On condition, I ſay, you inſtantly turn out that boy—that Henry.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Turn out Henry!—Ha, ha, ha! Excuſe my tittering, Zur; but you bees making your vun of I, zure.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I am not apt to trifle—ſend him inſtantly from you or take the conſequences.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Turn out Henry! I do vow I ſhou'dn't knaw how to zet about it—I ſhould not indeed, Zur.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: You hear my determination. If you diſobey, you know what will follow—I'll leave you to reflect on it.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p:
Well, Zur, I'll arguſy the topic, and then you may wait upon me, and I'll tell ye. (makes the motion of turning out)—I ſhou'd be deadly awkward at it vor zartain—however, I'll put the caſe—Well! I goes whiztling whoam—noa, drabbit it! I ſhou'dn't be able to whiztle a bit, I'm zure. Well! I goes whoam, and I zees Henry zitting by my wife mixing up ſomeit to comfort the wold zoul, and take away the pain of here rheumatics—Very well! Then Henry places a chair
vor I by the vire zide, and zays— Varmer, the horſes be fed, the ſheep be folded, and you have nothing to do but to zit down, ſmoke your pipe, and be happy! Very well! (becomes affected.) Then I zays— Henry, you be poor and ••• endleſs, zo you muſt turn out of my houze directly. Very well! then my wife ſtares at O—reaches her hand towards the vire place, and throws the poker at my head. Very well! then Henry gives a kind of aguiſh ſhake, and getting up, ſighs from the bottom of his heart—then holding up his head like a king, zays— Varmer, I have too long been a burthen to you—Heaven protect you, as you have me—Farewel! I go. Then I ſays, If thee docz I'll be domn'd! (with great energy.) Hollo! you Miſter Sir Philip! you may come in.—

div.p: Zur, I have argufied the topic, and it wou'dn't be pratty—zo I can't.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Can't! abſurd!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Well, Zur, there is but another word— I won't.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: No, Zur, I won't—I'd zee myzelf hang'd firſt, and you too, Zur—I wou'd indeed

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: You refuſe then to obey.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I do, Zur—at your zarvice

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Then the law muſt take its courſe.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I be zorry for that too—I be indeed, Zur; but if corn wou'dn't grow I cou'dn't help it; it wer'n't poiſon'd by the hand that zow'd it. Thic hand, Zur, be as free from guilt as your own.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: It were never held out to clinch a hard bargain, nor will it turn a good lad out into the wide wicked world becauſe he be pooriſh a bit. I be zorry you be offended, Zur, quite—but come what wool, I'll never hit thic hand againſt here, but when I be zure that zomeit at inzide will jump againſt it with pleazure (bowing). I do hope you'll repent of all your zins—I do indeed, Zur; and if you ſhou'd, I'll come and zee you again as friendly as ever—I wool indeed, Zur.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Your repentance will come too late!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Thank ye, Zur—Good morning to you— I do hope I have made myzel agreeable—and ſo I'll go whoam.

div.trailer: THE END OF THE THIRD ACT

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.—A room in ASHFIELD's houſe.
div.stage: Dame ASHFIELD diſcovered at work with her needle. HENRY ſitting by her.

sp.speaker: DAME.
sp.p: COME, come, Henry, you'll fret yourſelf ill, child. If Sir Philip will not be kind to you, you are but where you were.

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: My peace of mind is gone for ever. Sir Philip may have cauſe for hate;—ſpite of his unkindneſs to me, my heart ſeeks to find excuſes for him—for, oh! that heart doats on his lovely daughter.

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: Here comes Tummas home at laſt. Heyday! what's the matter with the man? He does'nt ſeem to know the way into his own houſe.
sp.stage: Enter ASHFIELD, muſing, he ſtumbles againſt a chair.
sp.p: Tummas, my dear Tummas, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
