sp.p: It be lucky vor he I h •• zoo pratty behaved, or dom if I—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Who—what?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Nothing at all, where's Henry?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Here, farmer.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Thee woult'nt leave us, Henry, wou't?

sp.speaker: Heny.
sp.p: Leave you! What, leave you now, when by my exertion I can pay off part of the debt of gratitude I owe you? oh, no!

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Nay, it were not vor that I axed, I promiſe thee; come, gi' us thy hand on't then (ſhaking hands). Now I'll tell ye. Zur Philip did ſend vor I, about the money I do owe 'un; and ſaid as how he'd make all ſtrait between us—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That was kind.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Yes, deadly kind. Make all ſtrait on condition I did turn Henry out o' my doors.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Where will his hatred ceaſe?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And what did you ſay, Tummas?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Why, I zivelly tould un, if it were agreeable to he to behave like a brute, it were agreeable to I to behave like a man.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That was right. I wou'd have told him a great deal more.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ah! likely. Then a zaid I ſhou'd ha a bit of laa vor my pains.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And do you imagine I will ſee you ſuffer on my account? No—I will remove this hated form—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p:
No, but thee ſhat'un—thee ſhat'un—I tell thee. Thee have givun me thy hand on't, and dom'me, if thee ſhat budge one ſtep out of this houſe. Drabbit it! what can he do? he can't ſend
us to jail. Why, I have corn will zell for half the money I do owe 'un—and ha'nt I cattle and ſheep? deadly lean to be zure—and ha'nt I a thumping zilver watch, almoſt as big as thy head? and Dame here a got—How many ſilk gowns have thee got, Dame?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Three, Tummas—and ſell them all— and I'll go to church in a ſtuff one—and let Mrs. Grundy turn up her noſe as much as ſhe pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, my friends, my heart is full. Yet a day will come, when this heart will prove its gratitude.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That day, Henry, is every day.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Dang it! never be down hearted. I do know as well as can be, zome good luck will turn up. All the way I comed whoam I look'd to vind a purſe in the path, but I did'nt though.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ah! here they are coming to fell I ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Lettun—lettun, zeize and zell; we ha gotten here (ſtriking his breaſt) what we won't zell, and they can't zell. (knocking again) Come in —dang it, don't ye be ſhy.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah! the ſtrangers I ſaw this morning. Theſe are not officers of law.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Noa! walk in, Gemmen. Glad to zee ye wi 'all my heart and zoul. Come, Dame, ſpread a cloth, bring out cold meat, and a mug of beer.
That is the boy.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Take a chair, Zur.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I thank, and admire your hoſpitality, Don't trouble yourſelf, good woman.—I am not inclined to eat.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: That be the caſe here. To-day none o'we be auver hungry: misfortin be apt to ſtay the ſtomach confoundely.—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Has misfortune reached this humble dwelling?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Ees, Zur. I do think vor my part it do work its way in every where.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, never deſpair.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I never do, Zur. It is not my way. When the ſun do ſhine I never think of voul weather, not I; and when it do begin to rain I always think that's a zure zign it will give auver.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is that young man your ſon?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: No, Zur—I do wiſh he were we all my heart and zoul.
Sir, remember.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Doubt not my prudence. Young man, your appearance intereſts me;—how can I ſerve you?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: By informing me who are my parents.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: That I cannot do.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then, by removing from me the hatred of Sir Philip Blandford.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Does Sir Philip hate you?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: With ſuch ſeverity, that even now he is about to ruin theſe worthy creatures, becauſe they have protected med.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed! misfortune has made him cruel. That ſhould not be.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Noa, it ſhould not indeed, Zur.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It ſhall not be.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Shan't it, Zur? But how ſhan't it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will prevent it.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Wool ye faith and troth? Now, Dame, did not I zay zome good luck would turn up?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, did I hear you rightly? Will you preſerve my friends;—will you avert the cruel arm of power, and make the virtuous happy? my tears muſt thank you

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Young man, you oppreſs me—forbear! I do not merit thanks—pay your gratitude where you are ſure 'tis due—to Heaven. Obſerve me—here is a bond of Sir Philip Blandford's for £. 1000—do you preſent it to him, and obtain a diſcharge for the debt of this worthy man. The reſt is at your own diſpoſal— no thanks.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But, Sir, to whom am I thus highly indebted?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My name is Morrington. At preſent that information muſt ſuffice.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Morrington.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Zur, if I may be zo bold—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, friend—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Don't be angry I had'nt thanked you, Zur, nor I wont.—Only, Zur, I were going to ax when you wou'd call again. You ſhall have my ſtampt note vor the money, you ſhall indeed, Zur. And in the mean time, I do hope you'll take zomeit in way of remembrance as'twere.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Will your Honor put a couple of turkies in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Or pop a ham under your arm? don't ye zay no, if it's agreeable.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Farewel, good friends, I ſhall repeat my viſit ſoon.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: The ſooner the better.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Good bye to ye, Zur—Dame and I wool go to work as merry as crickets. Good bye, Henry.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs your Honour—and I hope you will carry as much joy away with you, as you leave behind you—I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Young man, proceed to the caſtle and demand an audience of Sir Philip Blandford. In your way thither I'll inſtruct you further.—Give me your hand.

div.stage: Exeunt. MORRINGTON, looking ſtedfaſtly on HENRY, GERALD following.]

div.head: SCENE. II.—An apartment in the caſtle.
div.stage: Sir PHILIP BLANDFORD diſcovered—Miſs BLAND FORD reading.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Shall I proceed to the next eſſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What does it treat of?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Love and friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: A ſatire?

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: No, father;—an eulogy.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Thus do we find in the imaginations of men, what we in vain look for in their hearts.— Lay it by (a knocking at the door). Come in.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.p: My dear maſter, I am a petitioner to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: None poſſeſſes a better claim to my favour—aſk, and receive.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir. The unhappy Henry.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: What of him—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Emma—go to your apartment.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Poor Henry—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Imprudent man—

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.stage: (Sir PHILIP turns from him with reſentment)
sp.p: Nay, be not angry, he is without, and entreats to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I cannot, will not again behold him.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.p: I am ſorry you refuſe me, as it compels me to repeat his words: "If," ſaid he, "Sir Philip denies my humble requeſt, tell him I demand to ſee him."

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Demand to ſee me! well, his high command ſhall be obeyed then (ſarcaſtically); bid him approach.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: By what title, Sir, do you thus intrude on me?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: By one of an imperious nature, the title of a creditor.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I your debtor!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes; for you owe me juſtice. You, perhaps, withhold from me the ineſtimable treaſure of a parent's bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: To the buſineſs that brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Thus then—I believe this is your ſignature

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! (recovering himſelf) it is—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Affixed to a bond of £. 1000, which by aſſignment is mine. By virtue of this I diſcharge the debt of your worthy tenant Aſhfield; who, it ſeems, was guilty of the crime of vindicating the injured and protecting the unfortunate. Now, Sir Philip, the retribution my hate demands is, that what remains of this obligation may not be now paid to me, but wait your entire convenience and leiſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: No; that muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, why thus oppreſs an innocent man?—why ſpurn from you a heart that pants to ſerve you? No anſwer, farewell

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Hold—one word before we part— tell me—I dread to aſk it (aſide). How came you poſſeſſed of this bond?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: A ſtranger, whoſe kind benevolence ſtept in, and ſaved—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Morrington.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Fiend! tormentor! has he caught me!—You have ſeen this Morrington?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Did he ſpeak of me?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
He did—and of your daughter. "Conjure him," ſaid he, "not to ſacrifice the lovely Emma by a marriage her heart revolts at." Teil him the life and fortune of a parent are not his own. He holds them but in truſt for his offspring.
Bid him reflect, that while his daughter merits the brighteſt rewards a father can beſtow, ſhe is by that father doomed to the harſheſt fate tyranny can inflict.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Torture (with vehemence). Did he ſay who cauſed this ſacrifice?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: He told me you had been duped of your fortune by ſharpers.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Aye. He knows that well. Young man, mark me—This Morrington, whoſe precepts wear the face of virtue, and whoſe practice ſeems benevolence, was the chief of the helliſh banditti that ruined me.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: That bond you hold in your hand was obtained by robbery.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Not by the thief who, encountering you as a man, ſtakes life againſt life, but by that moſt cowardly villain, who, in the moment when reaſon ſleeps and paſſion is rouſed, draws his ſnares around you, and hugs you to your ruin; then fattening on the ſpoil, inſults the victim he has made.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: On your ſoul is Morrington that man?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: On my ſoul he is.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Thus, then, I annihilate the deteſted act—and thus I tread upon a villain's friendſhip

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Raſh boy! What have you done?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: An act of juſtice to Sir Philip Blandford.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: For which you claim my thanks?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Sir, I am thanked already—here (pointing to his heart). Curſe on ſuch wealth; compared with its poſſeſſion, poverty is ſplendour. Fear not for me—I ſhall not feel the piercing cold; for in that man whoſe heart beats warmly for his fellow
low creatures, the blood circulates with freedom— My food ſhall be what few of the pampered ſons of greatneſs can boaſt of, the luſcious bread of independence; and the opiate that brings me ſleep, will be the recollection of the day paſſed in innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Noble boy! Oh! Blandford!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What have I faid?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You called me Blandford.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: 'T was error—'T was madneſs.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Blandford! a thouſand hopes and fears ruſh on my heart. Diſcloſe to me my birth—be it what it may, I am your ſlave for ever. Refuſe me, you create a foe, firm and implacable as—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! am I threatened? Do not extinguiſh the ſpark of pity my breaſt is warmed with.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I will not. Oh, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes, on one condition—leave me: Ah! ſome one approaches. Begone, I inſiſt—I entreat.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That word has charmed me. I obey, Sir. Philip—you may hate, but you ſhall reſpect me.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: At laſt, thank heaven, I have found ſomebody. But, Sir Philip, were you indulging in ſoliloquy—You ſeem agitated.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No, Sir, rather indiſpoſed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I am deviliſh glad to find you. Compared with this Caſtle, the Cretan labyrinth was intelligible; and unleſs ſome kind Ariadne gives me a clue, I ſhant have the pleaſure of ſeeing you above once a week.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, I have been an inattentive hoſt.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh, no; but when a houſe is ſo deviliſh large, and the party ſo very ſmall, they ought to keep together; for to ſay the truth, tho' no one on earth feels a warmer regard for Robert Handy than I do—I ſoon get heartily ſick of his company—whatever he may be to others, he's a curſed bore to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Where is your worthy father?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: As uſual, full of contrivances that are impracticable, and improvements that are retrograde; forming, altogether, a whimſical inſtance of the confuſion of arrangement, the delay of expedition, the incommodiouſneſs of accommodation, and the infernal trouble of endeavouring to ſave it —he has now a ſcore or two of workmen about him, and intends pulling down ſome apartments in the eaſt wing of the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! ruin!—Within there!

div.p: Fly to Sir Abel Handy—Tell him to deſiſt; order his people, on the peril of their lives, to leave the Caſtle inſtantly. Away.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir Philip Blandford, your conduct compels me to be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Oh! forbear! forbear!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Sir,—an alliance, it ſeems, is intended between our families, founded on ambition and intereſt. I wiſh it, Sir, to be formed on a nobler baſis, ingenuous friendſhip and mutual confidence. That confidence being withheld, I muſt here pauſe, for I ſhould heſitate in calling that man father, who refuſes me the name of friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Ah! how ſhall I act?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Is my demand unreaſonable?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Strictly juſt—But, oh!—you know not what you aſk—Do you not pity me?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Why then ſeek to change it into hate?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Confidence ſeldom generates hate— Miſtruſt always.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Moſt true.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I am not impelled by curioſity to aſk your friendſhip. I ſcorn ſo mean a motive. Believe me, Sir, the folly and levity of my character proceed merely from the efferveſcence of my heart —you will find its ſubſtance, warm, ſteady, and ſincere.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I believe it from my ſoul.—Allow me a moment's thought.— (Aſide)—Suſpicion is awakened, does not prudence as well as juſtice prompt me to confide in him. Does not my poverty command me. Perhaps, I may find a ſympathizing friend—the taſk is dreadful—but it muſt be ſo—perhaps, he will perform the awful taſk of viſiting the chamber, and removing every veſtige of guilt. (To him) Yes, you ſhall hear my ſtory, I will lay before your view the agony with which this wretched boſom is loaded.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I am proud of your confidence, and am prepared to receive it.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Not here—let me lead you to the eaſtern part of the Caſtle, my young friend—mark me: This is no common truſt I repoſe in you; for I place my life in your hands.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: And the pledge I give for its ſecurity is what alone gives value to life, my honour.

div.head: SCENE III.—A gloomy Gallery in the Caſtle—in the Centre a ſtrongly barred Door.—The Gallery hung with Portraits.
div.stage: HENRY diſcovered examining a particular Portrait, which occupies a conſpicuous Situation in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Whenever curioſity has led me to this gallery, that portrait has attracted my attention— the features are peculiarly intereſting. One of the Houſe of Blandford—Blandford!—my name— perhaps my father. To remain longer ignorant of my birth, I feel impoſſible. There is a point when patience ceaſes to be virtue—Huſh. I hear footſteps —Ah! Sir Philip, and another, in cloſe converſation. Shall I avoid them?—No—Shall I conceal myſelf and obſerve them—Curſe on the baſe ſuggeſtion!—No—

div.stage: Enter Sir PHILIP and HANDY, jun.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: That chamber contains the myſtery.

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Obſerve that portrait (ſeeing HENRY—ſtarts). Who's there?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir, we wiſh to be private.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: My being here, Sir, was merely the effect of accident. I ſcorn intruſion (bows). But the important words are ſpoken—that chamber contains the myſtery

sp.speaker: Handy, jun
sp.p: Who is that youth?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
You there behold his father—my brother— (weeps)—I've not beheld that face theſe
twenty years.—Let me again peruſe its lineaments. (in an agony of grief) Oh, God! how I loved that man!—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Be compoſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I will endeavour. Now liſten to my ſtory.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You rivet my attention.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: While we were boys, my father died inteſtate, So I, as elder born, became the ſole poſſeſſor of his fortune; but the moment the law gave me power, I divided, in equal portions, his large poſſeſſions, one of which I with joy preſented to my brother.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: It was noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: At leaſt it was juſt—we lived together, Sir, as one man; as my life I loved him, and ſelt no joys but what he ſhared—Sorrow I knew not.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Such love demanded a life of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: You ſhall now hear, Sir, how I was rewarded. Chance placed in my view a young woman of ſuperior perſonal charms; my heart was captivated—Fortune ſhe poſſeſſed not—but mine was ample. She bleſſed me by conſenting to our union, and my brother approved my choice.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: How enviable your ſituation.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
Oh! (ſighing deeply) On the evening previous to my intended marriage, with a mind ſerene as the departing ſun, whoſe morning beam was to light me to happineſs, I ſauntered to a favourite tree, where, lover like, I had marked the name of my deſtined bride, and with every nerve braced to the tone of ecſtacy, I was wounding the
bark with a deeper impreſſion of the name—when, oh, God!—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Pray proceed!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: When the loved offspring of my mother, and the woman my ſoul adored—the only two beings on earth who had wound themſelves round my heart, by every tie dear to the ſoul of man, placed themſelves before me; I heard him— even now the ſound is in my ears, and drives me to madneſs—I heard him breathe vows of love, which ſhe anſwered with burning kiſſes—He pitied his poor brother, and told her he had prepared a veſſel to bear her for ever from me.—They were about to depart, when the burning fever in my heart ruſhed upon my brain—Picture the young tiger, when firſt his ſavage nature rouſes him to vengeance—the knife was in my gripe—I ſprung upon them—with one hand I tore the faithleſs woman from his damned embrace, and with the other—ſtabbed my brother to the heart.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What followed?—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: At that dreadful moment my brother's ſervant appeared, and the veſſel that was to waſt him to happineſs bore away his bleeding body; a few days brought the news that he had died ſuddenly in France, and all inquiry ceaſed
sp.stage: (exhauſted he falls into HANDY, jun. arms).

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You are faint—But let me lead you from this place—Yet hold!—the wretched woman—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Was ſecretly conveyed here—even to that chamber.—She proved pregnant, and in giving birth to a ſon, paid the forfeit of her perjury by death.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Which ſon, is the youth that left us.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Even ſo—Tell me, could wretch be born poſſeſſed of a more ſolid title to my hate?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yet, he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My taſk being ended, yours begins.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes, that chamber contains evidence of my ſhame; the fatal inſtrument, with other guilty proofs, lie there concealed—can you wonder I dread to viſit the ſcene of horror—can you wonder I implore you, in mercy, to ſave me from the taſk. Oh! my friend, enter the chamber, bury in endleſs night thoſe inſtruments of blood, and I will kneel and worſhip you.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Will you (embraces him)? I am unuſed to kindneſs from man, and it affects me. Oh! can you preſs to your guiltleſs heart that blood-ſtained hand.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir Philip, let men without faults condemn; I muſt pity you.

div.stage: Exeunt HANDY, jun. leading Sir PHILIP.

div.trailer: THE END OF THE FOURTH ACT.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.—A wooded view of the country.
div.stage: Enter SUSAN ASHFIELD, who looks about with anxiety, and then comes forward.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: I FEAR my conduct is very imprudent.—Has not Mr. Handy told me he is engaged to another? But 'tis hard for the heart to forego, without one ſtruggle, its only hope of happineſs; and conſcious of my own honor, what have I to fear? Perhaps he may repent his unkindneſs to me—at leaſt I'll put his paſſion to the proof; if he be worthy of my love, happineſs is for ever mine; if not, I'll tear him from my breaſt, tho' from the wound my life's blood ſhould follow. Ah, he comes—I feel I am a coward, and my poor alarmed heart trembles at its approaching trial—pardon me, female delicacy, if for a moment, I ſeem to paſs thy ſacred limits.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: By Heavens, the misfortunes of Sir Philip Blandford weigh ſo heavily on my ſpirits, that —but confuſion to melancholy! I am come here to meet an angel, who will, in a moment, drive away the blue devils like miſt before the ſun. Let me again read the dear words; (reading a letter) I confeſs I love you ſtill, (kiſſes the letter) but I dare not believe their truth till her ſweet lips confirm it. Ah, ſhe's there—Suſan, my angel! a thouſand thanks. A life of love can alone repay the joy your letter gave me.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Do you not deſpiſe me?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; love you more than ever.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, Robert, this is the very criſis of my fate.—From this moment we meet with honor, or we meet no more. If we muſt part, perhaps when you lead your happy bribe to church, you may ſtumble over your Suſan's grave. Well, be it ſo.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Away with ſuch ſombre thoughts!

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Tell me my doom—yet hold—you are wild, impetuous—you do not give your heart fair play—therefore promiſe me (perhaps 'tis the laſt favor I ſhall aſk), that before you determine whether our love ſhall die or live with honour, you will remain here alone a few moments, and that you will give thoſe moments to reflection.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I do—I will.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: With a throbbing heart I will wait at a little diſtance. May virtuous love and ſacred honour direct his thoughts!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p:
Yes, I will reflect—that I am the moſt fortunate fellow in England. She loves me ſtill—
what is the conſequence? that love will triumph—that ſhe will be mine—mine without the degradation of marriage—love, pride, all gratified—how I ſhall be envied, when I triumphantly paſs the circles of ſaſhion! one will cry, Who is that angel? another, "Happy fellow!" then Suſan will ſmile around—will ſhe ſmile? oh yes—ſhe will be all gaiety—mingle with the votaries of pleaſure, and—what! Suſan Aſhfield, the companion of licentious women! Damnation! no; I wrong her —ſhe would not—ſhe would rather ſhun ſociety— ſhe would be melancholy—melancholy, (ſighs and looks at his watch) would the time were over. Pſhaw! I think of it too ſeriouſly—'tis falſe—I do not—ſhould her virtue yield to love, would not remorſe affect her health? ſhould I not behold that lovely form ſicken and decay—perhaps die—die! then what am I? a villain—loaded with her parent's curſes and my own. Let me fly from the dreadful thought—But how fly from it— (calmly) by placing before my imagination a picture of more honourable lineaments—I make her my wife. Ah! then ſhe would ſmile on me—there's rapture in the thought —inſtead of vice producing decay, I behold virtue emblazening beauty—inſtead of Suſan on the bed of death, I behold her giving to my hopes a dear pledge of our mutual love. She places it in my arms—down her father's honeſt face runs & tear, but 'tis the tear of joy. Oh, this will be luxury— paradiſe!—Come, Suſan—come, my love, my ſoul, my wife!

div.stage: Enter SUSAN—ſhe at firſt heſitates—on hearing the word wife, ſhe ſprings into his arms.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes; thoſe charms have conquered.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh! no; do not ſo diſgrace the victory you have gained—'tis your own virtue that has triumphed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My Suſan! how true it is, that fools alone are vicious. But let us fly to my father, and obtain his conſent. On recollection, that may not be quite ſo eaſy. His arrangements with Sir Philip Blandford are—are—not mine, ſo there's an end of that. And Sir Philip, by misſortune, knows how to appreciate happineſs. Then poor Miſs Blandford —upon my ſoul, I feel for her.

sp.speaker: Suſan
sp.p: Come—don't make yourſelf miſerable. If my ſuſpicions be true, ſhe'll not break her heart for your loſs.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Nay, don't ſay ſo—ſhe will be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: There he is. Dame, ſhall I ſhoot at un?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: My father's voice.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Then I'll leather un wi' my ſtick.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Zounds—no—come here.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What do thee do here wi' my Sue, eh?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: With your Sue—ſhe's mine—mine by a huſband's right.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Huſband! what, thee Sue's huſband?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I ſoon ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: But how tho'—? what, faith and troth, what, like as I married Dame?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What, axed three times?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes; and from this moment I'll maintain that the real Temple of love is a pariſh church —cupid is a chubby curate, his torch is the ſexton's lantern, and the according paean of the ſpheres is the profound naſal thorough baſs of the clerk's Amen.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Huzza! only to think now—my bleſſing go with you, my children!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: And Heaven's bleſſing too. Ecod, I believe now, as thy feyther zays, thee canſt do every thing.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; for there is one think I cannot do—injure the innocence of woman.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Drabbit it, I ſhall walk in the road all day to zee Sue ride by in her own coach.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: You muſt ride with me, father.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: I ſay, Tummas, what will Mrs. Grundy ſay then?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I do hope thee will not be aſham'd of thy feyther in laa, woolye?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; for then I muſt alſo be aſhamed of myſelf, which I am reſolved not to be again.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Heyday, Bob! why an't you gallanting your intended bride? but you are never where you ought to be.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, by your own confeſſion I am where I ought to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No; you ought to be at the Caſtle— Sir Philip is there, and Miſs Blandford is there, and Lady Handy is there—and therefore—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You are not there—in one word, I ſhall not marry Miſs Blandford.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Indeed! who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: One who never lies—and therefore, one I am determined to make a friend of—my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: But, zounds, Sir, what excuſe have you?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: A very fair one, Sir—is not ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, yes, I can't deny it—but, 'sdeath Sir, this overturns my beſt plan.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No, Sir: for a parent's beſt plan is his ſon's happineſs, and that it will eſtabliſh. Come, give us your conſent. Conſider how we admire all your wonderful inventions.

sp.speaker: Sir Abe.
sp.p: No; not my plough, Bob—but 'tis a deviliſh clever plough.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I dare ſay it is. Come, Sir, conſent and perhaps, in our turn, we may invent ſomething that may pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: He! he! he! well—but hold—what's the uſe of my conſent without my wife's—bleſs you! I dare no more ſay I approve, without—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Health to this worthy company.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: The ſame to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Who have we here, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I wiſh to ſpeak with Sir Abel Handy.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: I am the perſon.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: You are married?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Damn it! he ſees it in my face.—Yes, I have that happineſs.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Is it a happineſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: To ſay the truth—why do you aſk?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I want anſwers, not queſtions—and depend on't, 'tis your intereſt to anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: An extraordinary fellow this!

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Would it break your heart to part with her?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir, that—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Anſwers—I want anſwers—would it break your heart, I aſk?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, not abſolutely I hope. Time, and philoſophy, and—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I underſtand—what ſum of money wou'd you give to the man who would diſſolve your marriage contract?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: He means ſomething, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Do you think ſo, Bob?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Would you give a thouſand pounds?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No; I would not give one; but I would give five thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Generouſly offered—a bargain—I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: But, an't you deceiving me?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: What ſhould I gain by that?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Tell me your name?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Time will tell that.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Sir Abel—where are you▪

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: That's your wife's voice—I know it.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I'll wait without—Cry, "Hem!" when you want me.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Then you need not go far—

div.p: I dare not believe it—I ſhould go out of my wits —and then if he fail, what a pickle I ſhall be in! Here ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: So, Sir, I have found you at laſt?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My honoured mama, you have juſt come in time to give your conſent to my marriage with my ſweet Suſan.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: And do you imagine I will agree to ſuch degradation?

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Do'e, Lady Nelly, do'e be kind hearted to the young loviers—Remember how I uſed to let thee zit up all night a ſweethearting.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Silence! and have you dared to conſent?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, no, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir, you had better cry—"Hem!"

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I think it's time, Bob—Hem!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: What do you mean by—Hem?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Only, my dear, ſomething troubleſome, I want to get rid of—Hem!

div.p: There he is—never was ſo frightened in all my life.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Gerald!

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: An't you dead, Gerald? Twenty years away and not dead?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: No, wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Wife! Did you ſay, wife?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Say it again.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: She is my wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Once more.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: My lawful, wedded wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, my dear fellow!—Oh, my dear boy! Oh, my dear girl!— (embraces GERALD and the reſt) Oh, my dear! (running to Mrs. GERALD) No—yes, now ſhe an't my wife, I will— well—how will you have the five thouſand? Will you have it in caſh, or in bank notes—or ſtock, or India bonds, or lands, or patents, or—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: No—land will do—I wiſh to kill my own mutton.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall kill all the ſheep in Hampſhire.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Sir Abel, you have loſt five thouſand pounds, and with it, properly managed, an excellent wife, who, though I cannot condeſcend to take again as mine—you may depend on't ſhall never trouble you. Come! this way (beckoning to Mrs. GERALD)—important events now call on me, and prevent my ſtaying longer with this good company. Sir Abel, we ſhall meet ſoon. Nay, come, you know I'm not uſed to trifle; come, come—
sp.stage: (ſhe reluctantly, but obediently, croſſes the ſtage, and runs off—GERALD follows).

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: Come, come—That's a damn'd clever fellow! Joy, joy, my boy! Here, here, your hands—The firſt uſe I make of liberty, is to give happineſs—I wiſh I had more imitators —Well, what will you do? (walks about exultingly.) Where will you go? I'll go anywhere you like—Will you go to Bath, or Brighton, or Peterſburgh, or Jeruſalem, or Seringapatam? all the ſame to me—we ſingle fellows—we rove about —nobody cares about us—we care for nobody.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I muſt to the Caſtle, father.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Have with you, Bob (ſinging). "I'll ſip every flower—I'll change every hour." — (beckoning)—Come, come—

div.stage: Exeunt Sir ABEL, HANDY, jun. and SUSAN. SUSAN kiſſes her hand to ASHFIELD and DAME.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: Bleſs her! how nicely ſhe do trip it away with the gentry!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And then, Tummas, think of the wedding.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I declare I ſhall be juſt the zame as ever—may be I may buy a ſmartiſh bridle, or a zilver backy ſtopper, or the like o'that.

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: And, then, when we come out of church, Mrs. Grundy will be ſtanding about there—

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: I ſhall ſhake hands agreeably wi' all my friends

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: Then I juſt look at her in this manner.

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: How doſt do, Peter—Ah, Dick —glad to zee thee wi' all my zoul
sp.stage: (bows towards the centre of the ſtage).

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: Then, with a kind of half curteſy, I ſhall—
sp.stage: (ſhe advances to the centre alſo and their heads meet).

sp.speaker: Aſh.
sp.p: What an wold fool thee bees't, Dame— Come along, and behave pratty, do'e.

div.head: SCENE II.—The ſame as Act fourth, Scene third,
div.stage: Enter HANDY, jun. with Caution, bearing a Light and a large Key.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Now to fulfil my promiſe with Sir Philip Blandford—by—entering that chamber, and removing—'Tis rather awful—I don't half like it, ſomehow, everything is ſo curſedly ſtill. What's that? I thought I heard ſomething—no—why, 'sdeath, I am not afraid—no—I'm quite ſu—ſu— ſure of that—only every thing is ſo curſedly huſh, and— (a flaſh of light and a tremendous exploſion takes place) What the devil's that? (trembling) I ſwear I hear ſome one—lamenting—who's there?

div.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: Bob!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Have you ſeen anything?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, my dear boy!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Damn it, don't frighten one—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Such an accident! Mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I was mixing the ingredients of my grand ſubſtitute for gunpowder, when, ſomehow, it blew up, and ſet the curtains on fire, and—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Curtains! zounds, the room's in a blaze.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Don't ſay ſo, Bob.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What's to be done? Where's your famous preparation for extinguiſhing flames?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It is not mixed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Where's your fire eſcape?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It is not fixed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Where's your patent fire-engine?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: 'Tis on the road.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Well, you are never at a loſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I don't know. I ſay, Bob, I have it —perhaps it will go out of itſelf!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Go out! it increaſes every minute —Let us run for aſſiſtance—Let us alarm the family.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes—dear me! dear me!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here, John! Thomas! ſome villain has ſet fire to the Caſtle. If you catch the raſcal, throw him into the flames.

div.stage: (Sir ABEL runs off and the alarm bell rings.)

div.head: SCENE III.—The Garden of the Caſtle.—The effects of the Fire ſhewn on the Foliage and Scenery.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The Caſtle in flames!—What occaſioned it?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Alas, I know not!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Are the family in ſafety?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Sir Philip is.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And his daughter?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Poor lady! I juſt now beheld her looking with agony from that window!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah! Emma in danger!—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Are you mad? the great ſtaircaſe is in flames.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I care not! Should we meet no more, tell Sir Philip I died for his daughter!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Yet reflect.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Old man, do not cling to me thus— 'Sdeath! men will encounter peril to ruin a woman, and ſhall I heſitate when it is to ſave one?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Brave, generous boy! Heaven preſerve thee!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Emma, my child, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: I fear, Sir, the Caſtle will be deſtroyed.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My child! my child! where is ſhe! ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Alas! ſhe remains in the Caſtle!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! then will I die with her!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Hold, dear maſter! if human power can preſerve her, ſhe is ſafe—The braveſt, nobleſt of men has flown to her aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Heaven reward him with its choiceſt bleſſings!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: 'Tis Henry.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Henry! Heaven will reward him— I will reward him!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Then be happy! Look, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! dare I truſt my eyes!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: He bears her ſafe in his arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Bountiful Creator, accept my thanks!

div.stage: Enter HENRY, bearing EMMA in his arms.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: There is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My child! my Emma, revive!

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Aye—now to unfold the myſtery —The avenue to the eaſtern wing is ſtill paſſable —the chamber not yet in flames—the preſent moment loſt, and all is cloſed for ever. I will be ſatisfied, or periſh.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Am I reſtored to my dear father's arms?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes, only bleſſing of my life! In future thy wiſhes ſhall be mine—thy happineſs my joy.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My dear friend ſafe! and the lovely Emma in his arms! Then let the bonfire blaze.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My young friend, do you mark? the flames will ſave the trial I impoſed on you. Behold —they already burſt from the eaſtern turret! Ere this they muſt have reached the chamber— that conſumed, the ſecret is with us ſecure.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Oh, father, this unkind man has refuſed me, and given his hand to that ſweet girl.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I confeſs 'tis true—Your eyes can only fail to conquer thoſe who are before ſubdued.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: But, Emma, where is your Henry? I wiſh to be juſt to him—I wiſh to thank him.

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: He has withdrawn to avoid our gratitude.—

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: No—he again ruſhed into the Caſtle, exclaiming, I will penetrate that chamber, or periſh in the attempt.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Then all is diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Huſh! for heaven's ſake collect yourſelf!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.p: Ah! (ſhrieks.) Thank heaven he's ſafe. What urged you, Henry, again to venture in the Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Fate! the deſperate attempt of a deſperate man!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes; the myſtery is developed. In vain the maſſy bars, cemented with their cankerous ruſt, oppoſed my entrance—in vain the heated ſuffocating damps enveloped me—in vain the hungry flames flaſhed their vengeance round me! What could oppoſe a man ſtruggling to know his fate? I ſorced the doors, a firebrand was my guide, and among many evidences of blood and guilt, I found —theſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: It is accompliſhed! Juſt heaven, I bend to thy decree!—Blood muſt be paid by blood! Henry, that knife, aimed by this fatal hand, murdered thy father!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Miſs B.
sp.stage: (placing herſelf between him and her father.)
sp.p: Henry! (he drops his hand.) Oh, believe him not! 'Twas madneſs! I've heard him talk thus wildly in his dreams! We are all friends! None will repeat his words—I am ſure none will! My heart will break!—Oh, Henry! will you deſtroy my father?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Would I were in my grave!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah, Gerald here! How vain concealment! Well, come you to give evidence of my ſhame?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I come to announce one, who for many years has watched each action of your life.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Morrington.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I ſhall then behold the man who has ſo long avoided me—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: But ever has been near you—he is here.

div.stage: Enter MORRINGTON, wrapped up in his cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Well, behold your victim in his laſt ſtage of human wretchedneſs! Come you to inſult me?

div.stage: (MORRINGTON claſps his hands together and hides his face.)
div.p: Ah! can even you pity me? Speak—ſtill ſilent— ſtill myſterious—Well, let me employ what remains of life in thinking of hereafter— (Addreſſing heaven) Oh, my brother! we ſoon ſhall meet again—And let me hope, that ſtript of thoſe paſſions which make men devils, I may receive the heavenly balm of thy forgiveneſs, as I, from my inmoſt ſoul, do pardon thee.
div.stage: (MORRINGTON becomes convulſed with agony, and falls into GERALD's arms.)
div.p: Ah, what means that agony? He faints! give him air!—
div.stage: (They throw open his cloak and hat.)
div.p: (ſtarts) Angels of mercy! my brother! 'tis he! he lives! Henry, ſupport your father!

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Ah, my father! he revives!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Huſh!

div.stage: (MORRINGTON recovers—ſeeing his brother, covers his face with ſhame, then falls at his feet).

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Crawling in the duſt, behold a repentant wretch!—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: My brother, Morrington!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Turn not away—in mercy hear me!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: After the dreadful hour that parted us, agonized with remorſe, I was about to puniſh home what your arm had left unaccompliſhed; when ſome angel whiſpered— Puniſhment is life, not death—Live and atone!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: On! go on!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I flew to you—I found you ſurrounded by ſharpers—What was to be done? I became Morrington! littered with villains! practiſed the arts of devils! braved the aſſaſſin's ſteel! poſſeſſed myſelf of your large eſtates—lived hateful to myſelf, deteſted by mankind—to do what? to ſave an injured brother from deſtruction, and lay his fortunes at his feet!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, is that atonement? No—By me you firſt beheld her mother! 'Twas I that gave her fortune! Is that atonement? No—But my Henry has ſaved that angel's life—Kneel with me, my boy— lift up thy innocent hands with thoſe of thy guilty father, and beg for mercy from that injured raint.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: O, God! how infinite are thy mercies! Henry, forgive me—Emma, plead for me— There—there

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But my father—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Charles!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Philip!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Brother, I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then let me die—bleſt, moſt bleſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No, no (ſtriking his breaſt). Here —I want thee here—Raiſe him to my heart.

div.stage: (They raiſe MORRINGTON—in the effort to embrace, be falls into their arms exhauſted.)
div.p: Again!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: If forgiveneſs be an attribute which ennobles our nature, may we not hope to find pardon for our errors—here?

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.byline: Written by MILES PETIT ANDREWS, Eſq SPOKEN BY MR. FAWGETT.

lg.l: So here I am—once more to bear a bob,
And for our Author do a friendly job;
Perhaps you don't know how to clap a Play;
Mind me—hand rattle hand—thus (claps his hands)—that's the way!
No doubt you think, though ſecond ſure to none,
I'm rather ſanguine about number One;
Aſk all the world, who everything would try,
And all the world will anſwer, I! I! I!
Your ſprightly Damſels ſeeking active fame,
Will rival ſchoolboys in each ſchoolboy game;
Give 'em but rope enough, they'll ſhine in ſkipping!
While many a lucky rogue may catch them tripping:
Others, with beauteous arm and lovely ſhoulder,
Conſpicuous to each accurate beholder,
Vaulting on toe, with tamborine and bells,
Surpaſs the heroines of—Sadler's Wells!
Nor leſs our Beaux excite our admiration;
Their ſhoulders too are worthy obſervation;
Not bare indeed, but cas'd in tenfold ſtuffing—
They need not, if they like not, feel a cuffing;
Nay what's more frequent, and preſerves as much,
They ſave the preſſure of a Bailiff's touch.
Stuffing's a charm attracts us every minute;
E'en female boſoms find protection in it;
Expos'd to open charms and powerful flattery,
Why not gain conqueſts by a well-maſk'd battery?
But truce to ſatire—Folly's loſt in doubt,
And this age enters e'er that age goes out:
None know, ſo none to blame can find pretext,
Whether we ſin laſt century or the next.
"You're a baſe man!" cries wealthy Madam Dump,
To her fond ſpouſe who took her by the lump,
"To hide a wench laſt week behind the ſcreen!"
"Laſt week, my love!—laſt Century you mean."
"Sure! ſays Miſs Lydia Lank, an ancient maid,
"You will not countenance that painted jade:
"I hate to name the odious word miſcarried;
"And yet the wanton minx was never married!"
"That's an old ſtory!"—"Old! two months or ſo."
"Two months! you dream! a Century ago!"
"Dam'me!" cries Daſh, "each age has its beginning!"
His chin quite buried in five rounds of linen;
"Think you we drive through life with too much haſte?
"'Tis neck or nothing with us lads of taſte!"
"Your taſte!" cries Dad; "I fear your credit ſhocks,
"The riſe of Cravats proves the fall of Stocks:
"Save then to-day, to-morrow we'll want ſome."
"To-morrow, Squaretoes! That's an Age to come!"
Since then from changeful Time's uncertain ſtate,
Our very foibles now are out of date;
Let the Bard's faults find ſhelter on the Stage,
And let his labours live at leaſt an age.
Chear with your ſmiles the Poet's growing joy—
A ſcanty harveſt muſt his hopes deſtroy;
To brighten future proſpects, all ſhould now,
With heart and hand unite to—Speed the Plough!
